'Advertising Problems
Advertising is not doing well. It is not just because of the bad economy. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the economy got worse. The problem is bigger and is happening everywhere. Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now markets are smaller. Ads for big brands should focus on small groups, but they often do not. This is where advertising is wrong.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you buy many things. Most are not advertised. You might buy a few advertised brands. In a year, you might buy a few hundred brands. For big items like cars, you buy even less. You do not buy many clothes, and most are not advertised. Even with other things like candy and medicine, you do not buy more than 400 brands a year.
There are 32,500 advertised brands. Let's look at the 9,500 brands that spend a lot on ads. Most people buy only 400 of these brands, not all because of ads. That is about 4 per cent. So, 96 per cent of ads are wasted. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for things you buy. For most people, it is about 1 in 16. The rest are wasted.
People think they do not listen to ads, but they do. Most people do not buy the brands they see in ads. Waste is part of advertising. Not everyone will buy what they see in ads. People only notice a few ads. But advertising can still work. It talks to many people to find the few who will buy. Ads are a cheap way to talk to many people.
Advertisers can try to waste less by targeting better. But they can never know who will buy. Even direct mail does not get everyone to buy. This is different from selling face-to-face. A salesman might sell to everyone he talks to, but ads cannot do this. If advertisers knew who would buy, they would not need ads. They could talk to people directly.
If an ad gets one million new customers, it is doing well. For soap, the top brands would be happy with a million new buyers. Any ad that gets 2 per cent of people to buy is very successful. This is a small part of the population. To reach them, ads need to be more focused.'

**Text for A1 Level:**
Charles Clover visits a special house in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This house is very good for the environment. It is called the 'autonomous house' and was made by Robert and Brenda Vale. They use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle waste to make garden compost. The house stays warm with heat from people and electrical appliances. 
The house looks normal from the outside. It has a clay roof and is near an old church. The house is very quiet inside because it has special windows. You must take off your shoes when you go inside. The house has a special way to let air in and out. Even the cats, Edison and Faraday, have a special door.
Robert and Brenda teach architecture at Nottingham University. They care about the environment. They wrote a book about green houses in the 1970s. They wanted a house that does not harm the environment. They do not use mains water. They collect rainwater and use it carefully. They do not have a dishwasher because they do not want to use strong soaps.
The house does not have water bills. It uses very little electricity. Soon, it will have solar panels to make more electricity. The house has a small wood stove for very cold days. In winter, the house is warm enough without extra heating. 
The house is simple and easy to fix. It was cheap to build. Many builders do not want to make houses like this.

'The camera and the fairies Arthur Conan Doyle, who wrote the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man. But in 1920, he saw photos of fairies in a garden and believed they were real. He published the photos and wrote about fairies as amazing creatures. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them with flowers. The photos looked nice, but they were not real. This shows that cameras can lie. Today, we can change photos with computers, but even in the past, photos were not always true.'

**Blacksmiths**
A long time ago, blacksmiths were very important people. They made weapons, armor, and tools for farming. People thought they were like doctors. Blacksmiths also made beautiful art. They made ironwork for big buildings like St Paul's Cathedral. 
In the 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths in Britain. Big factories did not need them anymore. But now, blacksmiths are becoming popular again. People like nice designs in their homes. Some blacksmiths make things that look old, like Victorian-style gates. 
There is a group called the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). They have an exhibition at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says blacksmiths can now use power tools. This makes their work easier. They can make many things, like bookends and staircases. 
Alan Dawson made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says working with steel is like drawing with metal. Susan May, a jeweler, likes how iron is soft when hot and hard when cold. Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles. She likes how steel feels strong and lasting. 
Iron is a special metal. It can be used to make beautiful things. People will probably use iron for decoration for many years.

'THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my friends was very angry. 'Why didn't you stop years ago?' she asked. I don't know how to explain. One afternoon, I smoked a lot, and four hours later, I stopped. It was strange. I went to a stop-smoking session two months and three weeks ago. It was a mix of group talk and hypnotherapy. I didn't plan to stop smoking. I liked smoking. It made me happy. I went to the session to write an article about people trying to stop. I said, 'I won't try to stop. I'm here to write, not to stop.' The counsellor looked at me. We could smoke as much as we wanted. The room was full of smoke, so we opened the windows. I noticed that when they told us to smoke, I didn't want to, and others didn't want to either. The stop-smoking ideas made sense. The idea of stopping felt good. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I do it? It was easy in some ways. The need for nicotine went away after a minute or two. It lasted only four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't. The hardest thing was being at home on weekend mornings. Smoking was something to do when I was bored. I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Doing things without smoking is new for me, like eating out or waiting for a plane. These are times I used to smoke.'

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British scientist. She won a Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964. She is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel prize. Many people in Britain do not know her name. Dorothy studied crystals. She found the structure of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She had three children and a husband who was often away. Dorothy loved her work and her family. Her life shows how she balanced science and family. It is important to know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

'Margaret and her special skill Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground with a forked stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a business to drill wells. They use machines, but to find water, Margaret only needs her stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time. This skill is called dowsing. Some people think it is like a 'sixth sense'. There are many ideas about how it works. Some say it is because everything vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, can feel these vibrations. In recent years, Margaret has been very busy because of dry weather. She helps farmers, people with holiday homes, and golf-course builders. Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near waste. The well should also be near electricity to run the pump. Margaret starts by looking at a map with a pendulum. The pendulum swings over places with water. Then, she walks with her stick to find the exact spot. When she is over water, she feels something special. The stick moves up when water is below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If Margaret and her husband do not agree on the spot, they keep looking. Margaret's skill is not common, but it helps her family business. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This skill helps her find water and keep their business successful.'

'We changed lives for a day! Have you ever wanted to live someone else's life for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to do something different? We helped four people do this - read their stories. Amanda (23), a young mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy (30), who works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant. A. Amanda's story I had never been in a place like it before. It was dark and noisy with many people. It was very different from my home. Being a mother is busy, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but the drinks fell off my tray and crashed on the floor. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. By 11.30 am, people were waiting outside, and I felt nervous. I was worried about remembering orders, but everything was automated. After a few hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. I had to say 'Pardon?' a lot, which was embarrassing! By 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to rest my feet. I couldn't believe it when a waitress said it was a 'quiet' day! I never knew waitressing was so tiring. I thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and calm. I'm shy, and I don't think I could work on a busy Saturday night. I wasn't happy with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was glad to go back to my children. It seems easy after waitressing! B. Cindy's story I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was excited too. I was told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. I was wrong! After Amanda left, I had to get the girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have some peace. Wrong! Amanda left a note saying I had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home, the real trouble started. They jumped on the sofa and screamed loudly! I thought they would get tired, but they didn't. I thought I had energy, but they beat me! After much persuasion, I got them to bed by 8 pm, but then they wanted water and to watch TV. It was tiring to spend all evening making deals with them. I never knew looking after two small children was so tiring. You don't have time for yourself, and the responsibility is big. Even so, I enjoyed the day. Rosemary (42) runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary (30), a teacher at a primary school. C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I get up at 5.30 am, so sleeping until 7 was nice! I didn't know what to wear. I couldn't wear overalls and boots! Looking at about 400 pupils at assembly, I hoped I didn't stand out. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, which was different from when I was at school. Then I helped with a nature project. By lunchtime, I was tired and wanted a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again. I went to a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a reading lesson and then a French lesson. This was fun because the children wanted to practise on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we went to the school hall for Physical Education. I was tired, but the children had lots of energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class. Teachers may get more holidays, but I think I'll stick to farming! D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm at 8.30 am, only to find Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's farm has 100 cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep! She makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk and making ice-cream. It was hard not to taste the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to check the sheep. I picked up a sheep that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours, they could die, so they have to be checked every day. After feeding the calves, I started the milking. It took two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, every day! I found it lonely. I missed the children - animals don't talk back! The worst part is not being able to get away from work. The cows always need milking, so it's hard to plan time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems nice, but the reality is different. The income is irregular, and I'd hate to depend on the weather.'

"Hakan Hardenberger is a famous trumpet player from Sweden. He was born near Malmo. His parents did not play music, but his father liked Louis Armstrong. When Hakan was eight, his father gave him a real trumpet for Christmas. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. Bo saw that Hakan had talent.
Hakan became very good at playing the trumpet. He did not want to play in an orchestra. He wanted to be a solo artist. He liked a French trumpet player named Maurice Andre and listened to all his records. Hakan's parents helped him follow his dream. At 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud also thought playing in an orchestra was not for Hakan.
Hakan entered a competition in Paris when he was 17. He did not win first prize, but he learned that people liked to listen to him play. Hakan believes music can move people, and he does not want to explain why, because it might ruin the magic."

'Five Jobs Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs: the good things, the bad things, and their normal workday. A. THE BRAIN SURGEON Name: Anne Age: 34 ANNE'S DAY "I wake up at 6.30am, go to the gym at 7am, and start work at 8am. I do surgery on Monday, Wednesday, and some Friday afternoons. I leave work between 6pm and 8pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my pager. On holidays, I worry about my patients and dream about surgery." B. **Career Power: Be a Good Leader**
A. What is a good leader? A leader is someone who helps and guides others. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, a writer, says leadership is about 'making things happen with people who are excited like you.' A good leader should speak clearly and with confidence.
B. John van Maurik, a teacher, says, 'Many people can be leaders, but they don't know it.' We all have some leadership inside us. We just need the right time and place to show it. We can see big leaders like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but leadership is also important at work.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you had. Both may have been good at planning and meeting goals. But the best boss made you feel good and helped you. The worst boss made you feel small and blamed you when things went wrong.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to follow rules. Leaders make new paths. A good manager keeps things running. A good leader can change a team or company for the better.
E. You can be a better leader. Here are some tips:
- Find what you love and lead with energy.
- Think of yourself as a leader.
- Sometimes you need to lead strongly. Try different ways to lead.
- Set goals and try to do better than them.
F. Leadership takes practice. You need to take risks and learn from mistakes. Learn to share work and motivate others. Be open to new ideas and keep improving your communication. You don't have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and help others become leaders too.

'Georgina McGuiness stopped working in journalism for a long time. She felt she didn't know much about new technology. She tells us how she changed her home into a good place to work. 'The end of print may take some time. Change can be scary for some people. But change can also be nice. Newspapers are changing to the online world. This change is not easy. Many people think newspapers will be online soon. Print newspaper sales are going down. But visits to newspaper websites are going up. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have fewer print sales, but more website visits. 
In some places, print sales are not falling much. The World Association of Newspapers says global print sales went up 1.1% last year. In Asia, print sales are growing. Online ads do not make as much money as print ads. Many US newspapers have paywalls. They sell print and online access together. Print is important for selling online subscriptions. **Taking Photos of People**
People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is often more interesting than one without. But, taking good photos of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move and their expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act differently.
**A. Group Photos**
When taking group photos, don't make people stand in straight lines. Ask them to stand at different angles or levels. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces.
**B. Posing for Photos**
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. They can fold their hands or put them in their pockets.
**C. Taking Photos**
Don't pretend you are not taking a photo. Most people will agree to have their picture taken. But they might feel shy, so you may need to guide them.
**D. Eye Contact**
A photo is strong if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. Remind them before you take the photo.
**E. Looking at Something**
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the photo. This can make the photo interesting.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**
Expressions and gestures show a lot about a person. A smiling child makes us happy. A sad face makes us feel sad. Look for familiar expressions like a thumbs-up or a wink.
**G. Backgrounds**
A background can make a photo more interesting. Make sure the background is not too busy. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger than the background.
**H. Interaction**
Photos of people talking or working together can be good. Look for eye contact or a handshake. Show how people react to each other.
**I. People and Places**
Many photos are taken on holiday. To show people and the place, use a wide-angle lens. Ask people to stand close to the camera. Make sure both the people and the place are clear in the photo.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Decide why you want the photo. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose. But family photos can be more fun if they are not posed. Candid photos show real moments.

**Sarah the Artist**
Sarah Janson is an artist. She makes paintings that look real. This is called trompe-l'oeil. Sarah does not sign her paintings unless someone asks her. She thinks the painting is more important than the artist. Sarah is very humble. She does not like to talk about herself.
Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for 16 years. She went to art school and learned to draw. She also studied graphic illustration. She worked at a publishing house but wanted to do more. She worked with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to make a trompe-l'oeil painting. She loved it and started her own business.
Sarah is very good at looking at details. She says you learn trompe-l'oeil by looking at things in life. She is always learning and says she is not perfect. She jokes that she cannot paint bread well.
Sarah has painted many big projects. Her work is very special. She likes to work with clients to make paintings that are personal. She listens to their ideas. Many clients become her friends.
Sarah is busy with work because people like her paintings. She does not like to talk about how good she is. She says her work is quiet, not loud. But her work is very interesting and deserves to be known.

'Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success Daniel Goleman talks about 'people skills' that are important for success at work. A The way we work is changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or our training, but also by how we handle ourselves and others. This is important for getting jobs and doing well at work. These skills are called emotional intelligence. They include social skills and personal qualities like being able to understand others and adapt to change. B In today's world, job security is not guaranteed. Personal qualities are important at work. Emotional intelligence means understanding and managing our own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, motivation, and empathy. It is not just about being nice, but also about managing feelings well. C Many businesses see emotional intelligence as important. It helps people work together better. In jobs that need teamwork, emotional intelligence is very important. D Unlike IQ, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. We can get better at handling emotions and understanding others. This is called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned and is important for job success.'

'Can the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and phones make it easy to take photos of news events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Some journalists use these photos from social media for news. Sometimes, they use these photos without asking. There is a rule that says you can use photos without asking if it is very important. But people still talk about if this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people would take a photo or video of a news event. This means these photos are important for the media. But, to keep a good relationship with people, the media should ask for permission and give rewards for these photos.'

**Acupuncture: An Old Chinese Medicine**
1. **What is Acupuncture?**
   - Acupuncture is a very old Chinese medicine, about 2,000 years old. It uses small needles to help with pain. It is part of a bigger system that also uses herbs, massage, and exercise.
2. **How Does It Work?**
   - In Chinese medicine, health is when the body's energy, called Qi (say "chee"), is balanced. Qi moves in the body along lines called meridians. If Qi is blocked, you might feel weak or sick. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulse, looks at your tongue, and asks about your health to find where Qi is blocked. They use needles to help Qi flow better.
3. **Where Are the Needles Put?**
   - There are over 300 points on the body for acupuncture. The needles might not be near where you feel pain. People say they feel a small ache or tingle when the needle is used.
4. **Does It Really Work?**
   - Some doctors think acupuncture helps with pain because it might block pain signals or release natural painkillers in the body. Many people with long-term pain, like back pain or headaches, try acupuncture.
5. **Acupuncture in Surgery**
   - In China, acupuncture is sometimes used instead of medicine to stop pain during surgery. This started in the 1950s. It is used in many operations, like heart surgery. People say it has fewer side effects than regular pain medicine.
6. **Is It Always Helpful?**
   - Not everyone feels better with acupuncture. But many people say it helps with pain after a few visits. It might take six or seven visits to feel a lot better.
7. **Choosing an Acupuncturist**
   - Some doctors learn traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific ideas. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. They should tell you to see a doctor if needed.

"P. D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She writes detective stories. Her books are very popular, and many people read them. P. D. James is shy, but she is very smart. She says the detective in her books, Adam Dalgliesh, is like her. She likes to be alone when she writes. P. D. James likes books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner. She also likes books by men like Graham Greene. P. D. James started writing when she was 42 years old. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband in Cambridge. Her husband was sick after the war, so she worked hard to take care of him and their two daughters. She worked for the National Health Service and the Home Office. She saw many dead bodies in her job, but she was not interested in death. She liked writing crime stories because it was like solving a puzzle. She thinks writing detective stories is a way to make order from chaos. She believes solving a crime shows that life is important."

'Handwriting and What It Can Show Some people think handwriting can show a person's character. In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. Companies use handwriting to see if you are right for the job. This is called handwriting analysis or graphology. Some researchers say handwriting can show if a person is sick or has emotional problems. Big companies use graphologists to look at handwriting for important jobs. But many doctors do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne is a graphologist. She says handwriting can show if a person is smart, honest, or has health problems. She thinks it can also show if someone might be a criminal. She says criminals often have messy handwriting. She also says handwriting can show if a person is under stress or has health issues. For example, if handwriting changes a lot, it might mean something serious is happening. Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to read handwriting well. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a real science. But some doctors say handwriting only shows how a person learned to write and does not mean anything else.'

'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for happy workers, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies work conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here is what they said.
Office A: Advertising Agency
- Building Health Consultant: This office is simple. No central heating, no air system, windows open to the street. The team of seven people is happy and works like at home.
- Ergonomist: The furniture is old and doesn't match. Chairs are broken and not adjustable. But the team has different tasks, which helps them not get tired or bored.
- Occupational Psychologist: Staff like the variety of work. The office is the right size, not too big or small. It is fun and creative.
Office B: News Service
- Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable. Air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.
- Ergonomist: Chairs and lighting are good. The office is grey and boring.
- Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare. Staff relationships are okay. Desks could be better for sharing information.
Office C: Bank
- Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. Air is not stale, even with smokers.
- Ergonomist: The office is standard and boring. Desks and chairs are not the best for computers.
- Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other. The office is busy but looks a bit dark.
Office D: Newspaper
- Building Health Consultant: The air system is bad, and the office is dusty. The roof collects dust.
- Ergonomist: Furniture is not good for computer work. Chairs are old and not adjustable.
- Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty and needs cleaning. People are stressed. The company needs team work.'

'Chewing gum is popular. Americans chew 12 million pieces every day. Chewing gum has less than ten calories per piece. It is a food and must follow American food rules. Today, gum is mostly made from man-made materials. It has pine resins and softeners for taste and texture. Long ago, the Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the mastic tree. American colonists chewed resin from spruce trees. In the 1800s, people sold spruce gum in the United States. Modern gum started in the 1860s with chicle from the sapodilla tree in Central America. Chicle made gum smoother and more elastic. But growing sapodilla trees is hard. Now, gum makers use man-made materials. Few people still gather chicle. They work in tough conditions with dangerous animals and insects. They climb trees to collect sap. They boil it and make bricks. Life is hard for them. Before, the U.S. bought a lot of chicle. Now, they buy very little. Gum makers use man-made materials to save money. Gum is said to help relax, give energy, and reduce tooth decay. Chewing gum for 20 minutes can help your mouth make more saliva. This helps protect teeth. Gum makers are always looking for new flavors. Most flavors are man-made, but some need natural help. America grows a lot of mint for gum.'

**Text for A1 Level:**
Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. 
Sue visits the Globe Hotel. The receptionist does not say hello to Sue. Sue thinks this is bad. The Globe Hotel has three red stars. This means it is a very good hotel. But Sue is not happy. 
The hotel has problems. The door from the car park is not watched. The corridor to the hotel is long and empty. The receptionist cannot find Sue's booking. The room is not nice. It is hot, and there is a hole in the wall.
The next morning, Sue tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He is surprised. There is a bad smell in the lounge. Sue says they should fix it. She also says the staff should not take guests to that room.
Sue likes Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress. Dinner is good. The hotel keeps its two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks how to get three rosettes. Sue says they should not serve a pudding that falls apart.
Sue's job is to tell hotels what is wrong. Sometimes people do not like what she says. But she must write a report for the hotel. The hotel pays for this report. 
Sue will not take away the Globe's red stars. But another inspector will come in two months to check again. Greaves says he will be ready.

'Climbing the Seven Summits Doug Scott talks about climbing the highest mountain on each continent. A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m) Doug and his friend Dougal were close to the top of Mt. Everest. Dougal started talking to someone who was not there. Doug thought this was because of low oxygen. Doug was worried about his feet getting cold. He remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes. Doug felt calm because Dougal was a good partner. They reached the top. B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m) Doug and Dougal climbed Mt. McKinley in April 1976. They carried their own food and equipment. The mountain was very hard to climb. They felt like they were higher than they really were. They reached the top and felt happy. C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m) In September 1976, Doug and Paul went to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up climbing Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle. They found a path and water. They changed their route and reached the top. D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m) In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to climb Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil. They decided to take an easier path because of time. They reached the top before dark. E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m) In November 1992, Doug's team went to climb Vinson Massif. The weather was very cold and windy. They reached the top in 8 hours. F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m) In 1994, Doug's team went to climb Elbrus. They used a cable car to go part of the way. They thought they reached the top but had to walk more. They went back down the next day. G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m) Doug's team wanted to climb Carstensz and meet local people. They were warned about danger but continued. They reached the top on May 12. This was Doug's seventh summit.'
