'Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her garden has many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden has many colors and shapes. The people who lived there before loved gardening. They left plants for Susan. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. Danny helps Susan. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas. But he understood when she said she wanted to paint them. Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She picks flowers and takes them to her studio. It can take a long time to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are busy for Susan. Tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan likes to watch flowers change. Tulips change shape in water. Susan loved plants since she was young. She studied plants in school. She liked wild flowers. Now, her garden has plants from other countries. Susan is busy with two art shows. She has a new gardener to help. But she still likes to work in the garden.'

'The Storm and the Tree Many trees in Brackham fell down in the big storm in March. The town lost two big lime trees in the market square. People in the town were not happy because the town looked different. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham was usually one of these people. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. Pelham was a strong man, but he felt very bad. His head hurt, and his chest was tight. His wife, Molly, told him to see a doctor, but he did not listen. He thought the police needed him. This made him forget things and get angry. His friend, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to say no. The doctor gave him medicine, and Molly took him home to rest. On Thursday, Molly told Pelham that the storm broke the walnut tree in their garden. Pelham was too sick to care. On Saturday, he felt better and got up. He saw that the room looked different without the tree. The Pelhams' house had a big garden. Pelham liked the house because the garden made it private. The walnut tree was nice to look at and made the room look good. Without the tree, the room was very bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The house next door was now easy to see. It was tall and had many windows. Pelham did not like the view. 'It looks bad,' Pelham said to Molly. But Molly was happy. 'I told you we need a new sofa,' she said.

'Living in the valley We lived in our valley for sixteen months when we first saw the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, before winter, even before November ended. Before that, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon snow began to fall. In one day, it was 15 centimetres deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we felt only strong gusts of wind; trees moved but the branches stayed strong. We knew we had to worry. The snow and wind were a problem, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which was usually gentle, that was the biggest danger. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams. Soon the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills. They moved and warned us of what was coming. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The snow was washed away as more rain came from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and was almost too full. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a big waterfall, as the water went over the dam and into the stream. The river was wild near our home, just a couple of metres from our cottage. It was deeper than we had ever seen it, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes came true as the dam held and the waters went down. Many times before the dam was built, the river flooded the nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river and usually all is well; the water from the hills stays behind the dam with just a little overflow sometimes. We can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel the power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel our home in the valley is safe.'

'Mark Adams is a film critic. He writes about films for a newspaper called The Front Page. This was his first real job. Before, he wrote about books and films for other newspapers and magazines. He also worked for the radio. Mark met Tom Seaton, who was the first arts editor of The Front Page. Tom also wrote for radio and TV. Tom hired Mark. Tom wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They had weekly lunches to choose what to write about. Mark felt lucky to be part of a new newspaper. He was surprised when he saw someone reading his review on the train. The team idea did not work, so they talked on the phone instead. People liked critics to focus on one subject, so Mark chose films. Now, Mark writes one long article each week about a film. He likes this way of working. He does not want to review every film. Mark thinks people choose films because of the stars, publicity, or director. He does not think reviews change people's minds much. Mark believes his job is to share his opinion, not to be right or wrong about a movie.'

Why does a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and run 10km? Because "it's fun." Melanie Sears is 17 years old. She likes sports. She wants a friend to train with her. The friend should like running, swimming, and cycling. The triathlon is a popular sport. People watch athletes swim, cycle, and run without stopping. Melanie started triathlons at 14. She won her first race because she was the only junior. She entered the National Championships but got lost and cycled too far. She cried but did not give up. Melanie works very hard. She was the top junior in the European Triathlon Championships. She wants to get better at cycling. Her parents help her with money for her sport. She trains a lot and does not have much time for friends. She talks to her team about their race times. Melanie wants to try harder races. She needs someone her age to train with.

'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why people like this hobby. Many adults like to collect things. It is fun and exciting. But remember, only collect things you love. People have collected things for a long time. Long ago, people collected stones because they liked their shapes and colors. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for the same reason. I have collected things all my life. I started with stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a faraway place in England. My parents took me to a museum with many old objects. I loved looking at them. Many people like collecting. Some people collect because it makes them feel in control. I collect because I enjoy it. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. You do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I once got a special tulip from another collector, but it was later stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I found them all over the USA. But my collection was lost in a house fire. I was very sad. Collections can change owners. This makes them special. Some old toys are now worth a lot of money if you kept the boxes. I did not keep mine.'

'My Job Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa - Exhibition Organiser, Science Museum I make exhibitions at the museum. I plan and design them. I read about the topic and talk to important people. I choose what objects and pictures to show. I make sure people understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities and bring in engineers to keep it safe. I also help make brochures to tell people about it. Janet - Teacher for Taxi Drivers I start work at 7.30 a.m. I check the money first. Then I make maps for taxi drivers to learn routes. About 50 students come to learn the best way to drive in London. I help when they have questions. I give them different routes to make them think. Sarah - Marine Conservationist I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls and make learning materials. I teach people about the sea. I take them on boat trips to see sea life. I love my job because I care about the sea. But I work for a charity, so we always need more money. Chris - Map Publisher I make sure we have enough books and maps. I talk to other publishers about new projects. I work with a happy team. I get many letters from readers and answer them carefully. I like my job, but there is too much paperwork.'

'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, Mr. and Mrs. Malseed, own the house. They made the house bigger, but it still looks nice. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel, but it was not good because the food was bad. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and I, have played cards together for a long time. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. "How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived. She always knows when guests are coming. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." These are the names of our rooms. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers. In winter, she does things like that, and her husband fixes the house. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, coming from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he said in an Irish way. He smiled with his eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and we felt our holiday had started. Nothing changed at Glencorn, all was good. Kitty from the dining room came to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our luggage to the rooms. After dinner, we played cards but not for long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From the window, we saw some people walking on the lawns and others going to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk to Ardbeag and have coffee there, then come back for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. We did this every year and loved the beautiful landscape.'

**Sarah's Job in the Mountains**
Sarah is 24 years old. She is from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isere, France. She is a chalet girl. A chalet is a wooden house. People come to ski and stay in chalets.
Sarah cooks and cleans for the guests. She started this job last year. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She likes this job because she meets many people.
Sarah wakes up at 7 a.m. She walks to the chalet. The chalet can have 18 guests. She makes breakfast for them. They eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms. She does not like cleaning.
At 11 a.m., Sarah goes skiing. She skis until 4:30 p.m. Then, she goes back to the chalet. She makes dinner for the guests. Dinner is at 8 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen.
Sarah sometimes talks with the guests. Other times, she leaves them alone. After work, Sarah meets her friends. They go out to have fun. But on Saturday, she does not stay out late. Sunday is a busy day.
On Sunday, Sarah starts work early. She makes breakfast at 7 a.m. for guests who leave. Then, she cleans the chalet. She also goes shopping if needed. New guests arrive at 4:30 p.m. Sarah helps them with their ski boots and skis. She makes dinner again. Sometimes, she is very tired and goes to bed early.

'Miss Rita Cohen, a small girl with pale skin, came to Seymour's factory one day. She looked very young, but she said she was older than Seymour's daughter, Marie. Rita wore overalls and big shoes. Her hair was curly, and her face was pretty. Seymour was surprised that she was at the University of Pennsylvania. She was studying the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. Sometimes, people called or wrote to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. He sometimes helped students by answering questions or giving a short tour. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class. Marie's class visited the factory once. Seymour showed them how he made gloves. He showed them the table where men shaped and pressed gloves. The table had hot brass hands that looked flat. Marie called them 'pancake hands' when she was little. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour said, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' Rita took notes and asked more questions. Seymour liked that she was interested. He told her about the tannery, where they make leather. He said it was an old industry, with remains found in Turkey. He said his father knew a lot about leather. Seymour asked Rita if she had seen anything made before. She said, 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' Seymour laughed. Rita reminded him of Marie. She was smart and eager to learn. Seymour said, 'We will make you a pair of gloves. You will watch them being made. What size do you wear?''

'Is it a fun job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi going to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. When you work for a pop star, you travel a lot. Raquel loves her job and likes her boss. But she has one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a long flight to California, I take sleeping pills to help me relax,' she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. 'It felt very closed in with small windows.' When not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She didn't apply for the job. She met a pop group manager by chance and got a job. She also took secretarial classes at night. Five years later, she got the PA job. B. David Brown David Brown was an accountant and a golf caddy; a person who carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more. You would too if you loved golf. But there are problems. You get a small fee and a part of the winnings. He earns between £25,000 and £35,000, but spends a lot on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for golfer Greg Norman. 'You don't just carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were noticed by European Tour Productions, and they made him a data administrator. He collects and studies golf statistics. TV commentators, golf magazines, and golfers want his results. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a newspaper. One of his easy tasks is to try food in top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? 'If people can pay, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember than buy a microwave.' His cooking talent got him a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, then a creative director at an ad agency, it was extra money. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. 'It meant earning 50% less,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job.' He still cooks at home and keeps fit by cycling to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. 'Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about foxes killing chickens. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'It's not easy, I have to work on them,' he says. 'I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I type out my morning notes with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy this part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help.'

'In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building. Around the building, there were big piles of soft sawdust. The sawdust was like golden mountains. One afternoon, Michael and his friends climbed to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs over the edge and looked at the lake. Michael said, 'I dare you to jump down,' and he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust. He laughed and said, 'I dare you all!' His friends were scared, but one by one, they jumped and laughed too. Later, they went back up to the roof to jump again. Everyone jumped except Michael. He was scared and stayed on the roof. His friends laughed and shouted, 'Come on, Mike!' But Michael was too scared to jump. He stayed on the roof for a long time. The sun was setting, and his clothes were wet from sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped. He fell on the sawdust and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. Michael felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner. His stepmother was not happy and said, 'You should be home on time for dinner.' She was a kind woman, but Michael did not listen. He was thinking about his friends laughing at him.'

'Job Help Are you not happy with your job? Do you want to change it? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people go to a careers adviser for help. You write about yourself and take some tests. The tests are called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with job ideas and training you might need. I tried Career Analysts, a big company for job advice. The test felt like a school exam. I was with ten people, answering questions quickly. The tests had things like finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked to an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts. I agreed with most of it. I was not good at science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse. But I was happy to hear I made a good choice with journalism. Changing your job does not mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to think about my skills and interests,' says Donna. She found out she was good at design. But she had to think about the cost of learning design. Other ideas were taking a year off and working in the Far East. 'I used my skills and now work in Public Relations. Career Analysts helped me see what I wanted to do,' she says. She told her friends about it, and they are happy too. Some people need help to find a new job. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. She took tests and found she liked sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. After the meetings, she decided to study geology. She is happier now. But job advice does not help everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, is a sales representative. She wanted new job ideas. She got many ideas but did not like them. They needed a big pay cut or a lot of training. She felt a friend could give the same advice.'

'Fun at the Dentist's? If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dentist office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a nice blue couch. Jerome says, 'Many people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared.' To help with this, he tries to make a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it makes people think of pain. Jerome wants people to feel relaxed and happy at the dentist. He uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. Patients watch a film about underwater animals while he checks their teeth. Then, they see a video of their own mouth. Most people like this. The office smells nice, like oranges, not like a dentist's office. Jerome says smell is important because the usual dentist smell can make people scared. Jerome is serious about his work. He uses warm water to clean teeth, not sharp tools. It feels strange but not painful. Jerome learned new ways to help patients in the United States. He thinks making it easy for patients is good for everyone. A patient comes in, and Jerome offers him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a dentist's office.'

'Chocolate is a big business Chocolate comes from South America. Now, people all over the world buy chocolate. At Easter, people in Britain spend a lot of money on chocolate. They spend over £230 million. People buy a lot of chocolate at Easter. They buy more only at Christmas. Chocolate is made from cacao beans. The cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant. It grows in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of the cacao tree is big like a melon. It has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl. This means 'bitter water' in the Aztec language. The Aztecs used spices in their chocolate drink. The Spanish liked it with cinnamon and sugar. In the late 17th century, people in Europe started to drink chocolate. In 1826, a man from the Netherlands, CJ van Houten, made chocolate powder. In 1847, a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, made the first chocolate bar. They mixed cocoa butter, chocolate liquor, and sugar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate. In 1905, the English company Cadbury made the Dairy Milk bar. Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies try new ideas to sell more chocolate. They make chocolate ice cream, drinks, and desserts. Cacao farmers have problems because the price of cocoa beans went down in the 1980s. Many small farmers had to stop farming. Think about them when you eat your next chocolate bar.'

'THE SHELL ARTIST Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He makes art with shells. He started this hobby ten years ago. Peter likes to make beautiful things with shells. He shows his work in his apartment. He says, "Tell me if I am boring you," but his work is very interesting. Peter did not plan to sell his art. Five years ago, friends said, "You should have an exhibition." So, he had an exhibition in London. Many people bought his art. His second exhibition opened yesterday. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition. Prices start at £225. Peter says he does not set the prices. He thinks his work is special. He wishes he started this hobby earlier. He says he is not as strong as before, but he still makes beautiful things. Peter uses small shells to make boxes, pictures, and flowers. He uses cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid for his art. He finds shells in many countries like France, Thailand, and Mexico. He only collects dead shells. He does not take shells with living creatures. He says, "The sea breaks the shells, so I collect them." His art is very beautiful.'

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. She travels to many places and is on magazine covers. But she also studies for her school exams. 
I went to meet Kira at her agency. The receptionist said, "Kira will be a little late." I thought about models. Are they difficult and vain? Will she be late for a long time? Maybe she won't come. But Kira came in smiling. She was with her mother. Kira wore a simple black dress and trainers. She was friendly and pretty.
Kira is a model because of her sister. Her sister sent Kira's photos to a model competition. Kira did not want to enter. But she became a finalist. She was at school when she got the call. She won the competition. Now, a model agency in London gives her work.
Kira has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too much of herself. Kira says she is more confident now. She can stand up for herself.
Kira's social life is different. The agency can call her anytime for work. She cannot always make plans with friends. But her friends understand.
Kira has a bright future. She is successful before finishing school. I asked Kira what she would do if she was not a model. She said, "I’d like to do what you’re doing."

'Father and Son Look for Gold Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son. They want to find gold. They traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa. Now, they are looking for gold in Wales. They think there is a lot of gold in a mountain in Wales. They have been digging for ten years. Terence is 68 years old and from Liverpool. He says they are close to finding gold. They read about gold in the 'Dolgellau gold belt' in Wales. They studied old books and newspapers. They found some gold in the rocks. They have been working for ten years. They need more money to keep digging. They hope someone will give them money. People in the town are interested. They think more tourists might come if there is gold. The gold industry in Wales was big in the 1880s. Now, it is not. But some people still look for gold. George Hall is another person looking for gold. He is 70 years old. He says looking for gold is exciting. He hopes to find gold too.'

'IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and studies the sea. She works at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes in a small underwater car. She dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean. She studies underwater volcanoes. Inside the car, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They stay inside until someone opens the door. A dive can last 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to work, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. A small escape car goes up fast to the surface. No one has used it yet. Rachel was nervous the first time she went in the car. She was with an instructor. He showed her what to do in an emergency. Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team put some equipment there. They want to study the volcanoes. When Rachel is not at sea, she is at her office. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research. She studies "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. Water comes out and looks like black smoke. It is very hot. Rachel was scared once. She was with an American team. There was a big bang. She thought she would die. But nothing happened. She was very happy to be alive. Rachel loves diving. She feels amazed when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them for real was amazing.'

I was dirty, smelly, and hungry. I was also suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired. My mind was tired too. I did not want to see more timetables, money, or languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the next. I only needed one train ticket. I was under 25 years old, so I could travel for a whole month in Europe. Sleeping in a train corridor is different. The train rocks you to sleep. I carried my things in a backpack. I sometimes threw away socks and books. This is the Inter-Rail way. You do not need to think too much. You just need a ticket. This ticket lets young people travel fast. On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special the ticket was. We thought it was a cheap way to go to a camp-site in France. But we wanted to travel more. There was always another country to see. And it cost us nothing extra. We liked culture, but this was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans. We only saw easy-to-reach sights. We did not want guided tours. We wanted something different. I liked seeing the view from the station. We wanted to have fun. We were like other Inter-Railers. We shared food, water, money, and music. Travel is exciting. A city is just a name until you see it. You see Europe by watching the landscapes and people. You understand Europe better this way. Other people's holiday photos are boring. The train trip is a personal experience. Europe is big. Inter-Rail helps you see this. But it took us some time to understand.

'It is very sad to arrive at an airport in another country and find out your bags are not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have the wrong clothes. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens. Even good airlines make mistakes, and they cannot promise your bags will be on the same flight, especially if you change planes. 
Airlines ask you to check in early so there is enough time for your bags to get on the plane. Sometimes, flights are late because of extra security checks or air traffic problems, and this can cause bags to be lost. Also, people can make mistakes, or the label on your bag can fall off. Big airports, called 'hubs', have many bags to handle, and problems can happen. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had many passengers changing planes. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have problems sometimes. 
To avoid losing your bags, try to take direct flights and check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline and give yourself more time between flights. Label your bags with your home and holiday addresses and flight numbers. If your bags are lost, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report before you leave the airport.'

'The Kingfisher
Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird. It lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. 
The kingfisher flies very fast. It is like a flash of light. Charlie James loves kingfishers. He loved them when he was a child. He does not know why he loves them so much. 
There are old stories about kingfishers. One story says a moon goddess became a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew high and got its blue color from the sky. 
Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. Their feathers reflect light. This makes them look blue or green. 
Charlie James likes to watch kingfishers. He hides and waits for them. He used an old blanket to hide. He waited near a kingfisher's favorite place. The bird came close to him. 
Charlie took many years to take a good picture of a kingfisher. He spent a lot of time near streams. He missed school to watch kingfishers. 
When he was 16, a nature magazine hired him. He worked as an assistant and then became a wildlife film cameraman. 
Charlie wants to make a film about kingfishers. He wants to show beautiful images of them. He loves the colors of the kingfisher. 
Charlie has spent many years with kingfishers. His photos show his love for them. But there is more to his love than the photos can show.'

'Conducting an Orchestra Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She helped him when his assistant was not there. She was not nervous. Anne works with an opera company in London. She also works in other European countries. B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He won a big competition in 1991. He says it is hard to get the right opportunities. He works with the English Chamber Orchestra. C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She likes the long practice time in opera. She started conducting in her late twenties. She worked in London before Pimlico Opera became professional. She learned a lot from Sian Edwards. D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He was surprised to start conducting. He worked with good conductors before. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano. He found it easier than he thought. E. WAYNE MARSHALL Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. Simon Rattle noticed him in 1986. He conducted a musical in London. He was tough with musicians who did not pay attention. He never studied conducting formally but knows what he likes.'

**Theme Parks in Britain**
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**
We went to Fun Island. We liked it. Our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special ride for very young kids. Older kids can try Splash Out, where you jump in a pool! After five hours, we wanted to go home, but the kids wanted to stay. The park is clean and safe. The staff is very nice.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**
We went to Wonderland. It was our first time at a theme park. Oscar, our youngest, loved it. He liked the Mountain Train and Little Land. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and toy cars. We stayed for six hours. The park is beautiful and the staff is friendly. There is fun for everyone.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**
We spent seven hours at Adventure World. The kids loved the Big Top Circus. We went on the Terror Line. The girls were scared but liked it. Their favorite was Running River. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The park is clean and the staff is helpful.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**
We went to The Great Park. It was open from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. The rides are not too scary. We liked Exotic Travels, a boat ride. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River. The kids loved it. The park is good for younger children.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**
We went to Fantasy World. It has Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket. Ben thought it was scary. Jennie thought the Hanger was scarier. There are many rides. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff was sometimes nice. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World.

'Running a business in the countryside Five women talk about their businesses in the countryside. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN. She has a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four workers. 'My husband and I moved from London to the country when our children were small. I wanted to work at home. I worked with computers before I was married, so my husband said I should start a computer design business. It needed a lot of money and was hard at first. But I was careful with money. I told the bank if I spent too much. Working at home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is a small business. People from the area come to us to get their work.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW. She designs greeting cards at home. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I married, we moved to the countryside, and there was no museum work. So I started my own business. I make 50 different cards and sell them to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working at home is there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I get business by word of mouth. I don't advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper. I work alone, so I don't share ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER. She makes curtains. 'I started my business eight years ago. It grew fast, and in two years, I made £80,000. I had six workers. But I had to let them go because the economy got worse. It was hard because there are not many jobs here. Now, I make curtains at home with my husband and other women who work from their homes. I have to lower my prices sometimes and look for new chances.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND works on children's books from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago. London was too expensive, and I love the country. I like working when I want. Most of my money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I take calls at odd hours. The bad thing is I need discipline to stop working. I publish children's books from around the world. I used to feel alone because all my work was in London.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six workers. 'I started ten years ago at home. I like health, so I made fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I sent cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building. We have a baker, an assistant, and a cake decorator. I don't cook now. I run the business side. My biggest problem was money because we didn't have much to start with.'

**Meet the Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is special. The sons, Paul and Huw, play music. Their dad, John, makes musical instruments.
John and Hetty Watkins live in South Wales. They have two sons, Paul and Huw. When Paul was ten, he needed a cello. Cellos are expensive. John wanted to make one. He went to a school to learn how to make instruments. After some practice, he made a cello for Paul. Paul used it for many years.
John stopped teaching and now makes violins. He even sold one to a famous American player, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano, then the cello. He liked the cello player in his dad's music group. Paul learned the cello and became very good. He won a big music competition and played in a famous orchestra. Now, he plays a very old cello from the Royal Academy of Music.
Huw plays the piano and writes music. He is also doing well.
The Watkins family is busy with music. Paul will be on TV playing his cello. Huw's music will be played in London. John and Hetty are proud of their sons.

'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is a group that takes care of the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knows the area and has farming experience. He still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. Gareth's job is hard work, like building fences and planting trees. He has learned a lot about nature. He remembers picking flowers and collecting bird nests as a child. He now sees how farming has changed the countryside. Farmers and conservationists used to disagree, but now they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's job is to make sure work is done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects and talking to people, but some visitors can be rude. Gareth loves his job and says if you have common sense and like being outside, you might want to be a warden too. But there might not be a job on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!'

'The Netball Captain
Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. She is getting ready for the World Championships next month. Every day, she teaches at a school and then trains in a car park. She says she is very focused on her training.
Kendra wants to be very fit for the Championships. This is her fourth time at the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. England will have many fans watching. Kendra says it is important to play well because people expect it.
England's first game is against Barbados. Kendra says they have always won against Barbados, but it will be a fun game. England is the fourth-best team in the world. The World Championships are hard because there is only one chance to win.
Kendra has played netball for 15 years. The game is faster now. Players train hard to win. After the game, players are friendly. Fitness is very important. Kendra wants to be a good leader for her team.
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided this will be her last competition as a player. She might coach young players in the future. At the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional because it is her last big event.'

'MUSIC SCHOOLS FOR SPECIAL CHILDREN What can you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents do not see their child's talent until the child becomes upset. Regular schools may not have the right help for children who are very good at music. These children might do well at a special music school. In Britain, there are five special music schools. These schools help children aged seven to eighteen to get better at music. They learn from professional musicians. Children at these schools spend a lot of time on music. They have lessons, play in groups, and practice singing and instruments. They also learn subjects like English, maths, and science. These schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school. This means they are with other children who love music too. There are some problems. The schools are expensive, but they try to help with money if the child is very talented. Also, some parents do not want their young children to live away from home. Some school directors think it is not good for very young children to be in such a strict place. They want to help children become happy and balanced people. Being away from other children can be hard. Some children lose interest in music as they grow up. The schools watch the children closely and help them if needed. Some children feel they do not learn enough other subjects. Many smart children want to learn more than just music. It might be better to wait until the child is older to decide about a special music school. Some children can do well in regular schools with good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges. But this is hard for families who do not live near big cities.'

'Susan Shepherd is an artist. She paints flowers. Her garden has many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. The garden has many colors and shapes. The people who lived there before loved gardening. They left plants for Susan. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. Danny helps Susan. Susan paints one flower at a time. She takes flowers to her studio. It can take a long time to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are busy for Susan. Tulips and poppies bloom then. Susan likes to watch flowers change. She studied plants in school. She liked wild flowers. Now, her garden has plants from other countries. Susan is busy with her art shows. She has another gardener to help. But she still likes to work in the garden.'

'Sarah's Job in the Mountains Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is 24 years old and from West Sussex. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is a chalet girl. She cooks and cleans for people who come to ski. The houses are called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is fun for a year or two. Sarah wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. The chalet can have 18 guests. She makes breakfast for them. They eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans the rooms or makes afternoon tea. At 11 a.m., she goes skiing. She skis until 4.30 p.m. Then, she goes back to the chalet to make dinner. Dinner is at 8 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. Sometimes she talks with the guests. Sarah meets her friends at night. They go out but not too late on Saturday. Sunday is a busy day. She makes breakfast early and cleans the chalet. New guests come at 4.30 p.m. Sarah helps them with skis and boots. Then, she makes dinner again. Sometimes she is very tired and goes to bed early.'

'Changing Jobs for a Day
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent one day at the magazine Marie Claire. She usually wears a uniform, but she had to choose clothes for this day. She visited a photo studio and press previews. At the zoo, she is calm and quiet. At the magazine, people were busy and stressed. She laughed because she usually cleans cages and handles rats. Mandie likes her job at the zoo and wants to stay there.
Alice Cutler works at Marie Claire. She spent one day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt. She got very dirty. She liked touching the elephants. She thought Mandie was packing clothes. Alice had a great day and wants to work with elephants in Africa one day.
Karen Hodson is a nurse. She spent one day with the TV show Ground Force. She was excited to meet the team. She liked being outside. Her job is inside, and she sometimes does not see daylight. The work was hard, but fun. She felt weak compared to the team. She likes gardening but will not leave her job as a nurse.
Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. She worked one day at a hospital. She made beds and gave out medicine. She thought she would faint but was okay. She liked the friendship among nurses. Her job felt less important than nursing. She felt good after working at the hospital.
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent one day with Ryanair as cabin crew. She wore a uniform and felt different. She learned about safety and helped passengers. She felt shy when people looked at her. On the flight back, there were many children. She wanted to be back in the gym.
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess. She spent one day as a personal trainer. She was worried because she does not exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. She meets many passengers every day. She saw trainers do not always eat healthy but drink water. She does not want to change jobs but wants to be healthier.'

'On the Train Five famous people tell Andrew Morgan about their best train trips. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I love the south of France. I go there a lot. There is a train from Cannes to Italy. It goes by the sea. The view is always beautiful. You can see nice houses and gardens. The people on the train are fun. There are tourists and local people. They all enjoy the trip. Raj Patel - Explorer I like many train trips. My favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip. I was too young and stayed with my aunt. I first saw a big train station in London. It was amazing. Betty Cooper - Novelist I love the Blue Train. My husband and I took it on our honeymoon in France. He gave me a pink dress on the train. I love pink now. The trip was nice. We went to Egypt by boat. It was a great way to relax after our wedding. Martin Brown - Journalist We were on a world trip. We had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The train did not have a set time. Many people got on the train. Some even rode on the roof. The view at night was beautiful. It was like a dream. Arisu Mezuki - Actress I did not see many trains as a child. I lived in Singapore and Cyprus. I saw more trains as a teenager. I made a film in Yorkshire with a train. The train was old but nice. I love steam trains now. When I went back last year, everything was the same.'

'Do you want to publish your story? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I wrote a story. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice writing. To sell your story, you need to know about the writing world. Read a lot to learn what publishers like. Visit your library and bookshops. Publishers always want new writers. If you want to write love stories, find magazines that publish them. Read these magazines to see what stories they like. Writers often ask, 'My story was rejected. Should I keep trying?' I say yes, but maybe the story is not ready. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you wrote only one story, it might not get published. Success usually comes after many tries. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Each story will be better. Don't throw them away; improve them. Don't show your work to others too soon. Remember, all writers face rejection. Try to join a writing course or group. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day.'

**Waiting for the Train**
It was the last day of a bad year. I was at the Baltimore train station. I wanted to take the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were many people at the station. The benches were full. Many college students sat on the floor with their bags.
A man with grey hair was talking to people. He looked rich. He wore nice clothes. He asked a woman, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said no. Then he asked a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I wanted to talk to her too. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "No, I am going to New York." The man said, "Thanks," and moved on.
I was going to Philadelphia. But the man did not ask me. He thought I looked unreliable. He asked an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington." He moved on. He looked worried.
He asked a woman reading a book, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Yes." He asked her for a favor. I listened. The man said, "My daughter is flying today. She forgot her passport. She is in Philadelphia. Can you take her passport to her?"
The woman asked, "Why don't you go?" The man said, "My wife is in a wheelchair. I can't leave her alone." The man had a big envelope. It looked strange. I thought, "Be careful, lady."

'Gary and Me John Moore is a restaurant owner. He talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking. My chance was to run a restaurant. When I found the restaurant, it was not in good shape, but it was perfect for me. I remembered my childhood. My mother worked in a factory, and I was sad because I was alone. So, I wanted time for family. My wife took care of the children and helped with the business. We lived above the restaurant. We always ate meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. They talked to our customers from a young age. Gary was a lively child. When he was seven, he jumped into a bath like a pool and got hurt. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and worked in the kitchen. He had a lot of money at school. He was disciplined. He woke up early. It was nice to see him help in the family business. Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. At 15, he was as good as the other workers. He sometimes was in charge. He made many meals. I knew he would work in cooking. When he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary now plays the drums and has a band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if his music becomes popular. I told Gary to focus on one thing. He understood when I said, 'Gary, you need to succeed by 30.' Gary went to cooking school at 17. On his first day, he finished his work quickly and helped others. I am very proud of Gary. His TV show is very successful. I always told him to work hard for what he wants. He listened to me sometimes, and I am happy about that.'

'Finding a Flat in Dublin Jo wanted to find a flat in Dublin. It was hard to find a good flat. Jo did not know anyone in Dublin. She stayed in a hostel and looked for a flat. Jo felt Dublin was a big unknown place. She did not know why she was going there. Everyone at her school wanted to leave their small town. Some friends went to Ennis or Limerick. Jo was the only one going to Dublin. Jo's mother wanted her to stay in the hostel. Her father hoped it was warm. Her sisters thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo saw an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to her work at the post office. Jo hoped it was nice and not too expensive. There was no line for this flat. It was more like 'Third Girl Wanted.' Jo thought it might be too fancy because it had a TV. The house was red-brick and had a basement. The flat was upstairs. A girl was leaving and said, 'Desperate place. They're both awful.' Jo went up. A girl named Nessa said, 'Did you see that girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' Jo asked, 'What did she do?' Nessa said the girl just looked around and made a face. Pauline, another girl, wore a very colorful shirt. Jo was surprised. Pauline was a punk. Jo said, 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office.' Nessa offered tea. She had three mugs: 'Nessa,' 'Pauline,' and 'Other.' Nessa said they would put Jo's name on a mug if she stayed.'

'Dolphins and Their Problems People like dolphins. We watch them at the beach, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins have problems. Mark Simmonds talks about this. Dolphins are smart and can feel human emotions. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But real life is hard for dolphins. The seas are dirty and have too much fishing. One type of dolphin, the North Sea harbour porpoise, has lost many of its kind. We think dolphins are safe, but they are not. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we see striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. Striped and common dolphins live far in the sea. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be near the coast. Now, they are only in a few places in Scotland and Wales. They have skin injuries and are stressed. Dolphins have complex lives, so it is hard to know why their numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. Dolphins need fish to eat. If there are no fish, dolphins cannot find food. They can also get caught in fishing nets. Many dead dolphins are found on beaches in France and Cornwall. They have marks from nets. Pollution is another problem. Waste in the sea can make dolphins sick. Pesticides can build up in their bodies. A baby dolphin can die from its mother's milk if it has too many pesticides. Noise is also a problem. Dolphins use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. We do not know how much this affects them.'

'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your body and mind. It helps you feel good when life is busy and stressful. Exercise is good for you in many ways. It makes your muscles strong and changes your body shape. It helps you stand and sit well. Exercise is good for your heart and lungs. It can also help you feel less sad and tired. Exercise helps you sleep better and feel less stressed. There are many types of exercise like jogging, lifting weights, and aerobics. Be careful not to exercise too hard at first. If you are not sure, ask your doctor what is good for you. Good posture is important too. Stand up straight and imagine a balloon pulling your head up. This helps you breathe better and look slimmer. Stretching is also important. It makes your body flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching four or five times a week is good. A good exercise routine includes warming up, stretching, working out, and cooling down.'

'IN THEIR NATURAL HOME Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa. They are in the Ngorongoro Crater now. It has rained a lot for six months. This makes problems. Owen said they bought a special tool. When their car gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can help him. Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films. They made a film about leopards. Now, they are filming jackals. Film-makers travel a lot to show animals on TV. I talked to Owen at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue, but they are friends again quickly. They do not have a leader. They both love animals. They sleep in tents. They make tea the night before and keep it warm. They eat pre-packed meals. They can be away for eight weeks. It is hard, but they like being close to animals. Once, a lioness greeted their car like it was part of her family. Owen and Amanda first worked together in 1988. They filmed Arctic foxes two years later. They need four months to make a half-hour film. They write a script before filming. Owen says they work well together because they have the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals. They want to touch people's hearts.'

'The Netball Captain
Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. She is getting ready for the World Championships next month. Every day, she teaches at a school and then trains in a supermarket car park. She does not notice people looking at her because she is focused on her training.
Kendra wants to be her best for the Championships. This is her fourth time playing in the World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. England will have many fans watching and cheering. Their first game is against Barbados. England usually wins against them, but it will be a fun game.
England is the fourth-best team in the world. The World Championships are hard because there is only one chance to win. Kendra has played netball for 15 years. The game is faster and harder now. After the game, players are friendly.
Netball players now use science to help with fitness. Kendra thinks it is important to be strong and help her team. She plans to stop playing after this competition. She might coach young players in the future. At the opening ceremony, she might feel emotional, and her fans will support her.'

'Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies the sea. She teaches at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes in a small underwater car. She dives three kilometers down to study volcanoes under the sea. Inside the car, it is very small. She can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move. They stay inside for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to work, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. A small escape car goes up fast. No one has used it yet. Rachel was nervous the first time. She learned what to do in an emergency. Now, she has made six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team. They went to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many volcanoes there. The Russian team put equipment there to study a volcano. When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office. She loves teaching, but she also loves her research. She studies "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes. They look like they blow black smoke. The water comes out very fast and very hot. Rachel was scared once with an American team. There was a loud bang. She thought she would die. But nothing happened. She was very happy to be safe. Rachel loves diving. She feels wonder when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. Seeing them was amazing.'

**Interview Tips**
When you meet someone for the first time, they quickly decide what they think about you. They look at your clothes, eyes, body, and how you talk. Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She said, "I worked hard for my degree. I was very confident when I finished school." She tried to get a job at a school. She had an interview with the Head Teacher. "I saw a small hole in my jacket that morning," she said. "I wanted to change, but I didn't want to be late. Being on time is important." Mary did not get the job. Her friend said the Head Teacher thought, "If she doesn't look her best for an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look after themselves will look after their jobs. In an interview, you should look your best." Some people forget this. Janet Goodwood worked for ten years in an office. She wanted a better job but did not get an interview. She asked why. The boss said she did not look like a manager. He told her to dress better next time. Janet was surprised. She thought her work was good, and clothes should not matter.
How you move and your face also matter in an interview. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian says 7% of our message is words, 38% is voice, and 55% is face. If your face and words are different, people believe your face. So, make sure your face and words match. Do not look too eager for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing expert, got a job offer in an interview. She was very happy. But because she was too excited, the boss gave her less money. She thinks she could have got more if she was calmer.
What you say and how you say it is important. David Artesio, a job agency manager, says to learn about the company before the interview. Talk about something you like about the company. This shows you are interested. Marian Woodall, a business consultant, says to have some questions ready. Speak in short sentences, not long ones. She says, "Good communicators use short sentences."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel. Now, he sells meat to the hotel and by mail. He works a lot but is happy not to be in an office.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He and his family moved to the north of England. They left their friends but still keep in touch.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats. She liked her job but worked too many hours. She left because she did not want to work more. She is happy now and less stressed. She misses talking to colleagues. She likes being responsible for her work.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He left his job and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health. He studied massage and got a job at the Life Centre. He is happy and feels in control now.

'Young Sports Stars Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I like sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried to join a football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. I hoped for more attention and money for training, but it did not happen. I train at home in winter and go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun, but I must be serious. If friends ask me to go out before training, I say no. I want to go to the next Olympics. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing world is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. I do not go to parties at night. I like to sleep late, but I cannot. It is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate. Winning the championship helped me get a TV job. Now, I am a bit famous. C Dieter (yacht racer) On the boat, we have fun. We celebrate wins a lot. Some people say we act like kids, but we do not look for media attention. Reporters care more about our parties than our races. I am away for eight months a year, so I like to come home and see friends. I do not want to be a celebrity. I get letters from fans and I reply to all. D Tomas (tennis player) It is nice when the crowd cheers for me. At the last tournament, it was very busy with fans. I like when fans see me in public, but my last girlfriend did not like it. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you must be serious in sports. I focus on my game now and will enjoy other things after I stop playing.'

**Shopping with Children**
Shopping with children can be very hard. One mother says, "They want everything. They see cereal, videos, and comics. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad when I say no, but I also feel bad when I buy them. I try not to take them shopping, but then they don't learn how to choose things. I can't win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want things. Parents find it hard to explain why they can't buy everything. Ads make things look very nice, even if they are not healthy.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Parents care about what their children eat. They have ideas about healthy food, but ads give children a different view. Parents don't like competing with ads and saying no to their children."
TV ads can't tell children to ask parents to buy things, but they still make children want them. Parents feel stressed deciding what to buy. One mother says her son watches ads but they talk about them. Now, he doesn't ask for things she won't buy.
Parents sometimes say no to children but buy treats for themselves. Mike, a father, says, "We say no to sweets for our son but buy chocolate for us. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I get annoyed by their asking. It depends on my mood. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to always say the same thing."
Supermarkets can help by not putting sweets near checkouts or having play areas for children. Parents might buy less, but more people might shop there because it's easier without children asking for things.

**The Merrion Hotel**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It is made from four old houses. The hotel has new technology for staff and guests. The manager, Peter MacCann, wants staff to know guests' names. The hotel computer helps with guest preferences. It cost a lot of money but is very useful. For example, if a guest likes certain music, it will be ready for them next time.
Guests can change the room temperature a little. The front desk can change it more. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has phones, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for new technology changes. TVs and DVD players can be updated easily.
The hotel has 145 big, nice rooms. There is a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, restaurants, and a garden. The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud has a famous restaurant in the hotel. The hotel and restaurant both benefit from this.
The Merrion Hotel has good technology and staff. It will do well.

'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women how they stay energetic. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I get energy from excitement. I like doing new things. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dance gives me energy. If you are bored, you can feel tired. Doing something useful gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. If you like what you do, you don't feel tired. I need a lot of sleep. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week. Exercise makes me feel good. I feel tired in the afternoon, so I eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I get energy from being positive. I don't like negative people. I enjoy life and set goals. I love my job. I like taking photos and writing songs for fun. It helps me relax when I travel.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'I get energy from things I enjoy. I love working with kids. They give me energy. Smiling at people makes me feel good. I try to eat healthy and don't smoke or drink. I play with kids for exercise.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'I love making gardens. I once turned a concrete place into a garden. It gave me more energy than exercise. I also get energy when people read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it's private land.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I think you should like what you do. I get bored easily, so I try new things. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. Use your energy for important things.'

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating is very old. People have skated for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, they used iron skates. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was important. 
In 1924, a girl named Sonja Henie changed skating. She made it more athletic. Now, skating is both art and sport. It is beautiful and hard work.
When you start skating, balance is important. You need to control your body. Your legs should be a little bent, and your knees should be soft. Relaxing is very important. To start, your heels should be close, and your feet should point out. Push with one foot and move the other foot a little. 
Falling is normal. Even good skaters fall. To fall safely, stay relaxed. To get up, use your hands and knees, then stand.
There are different types of skating: figure skating, freestyle, speed skating, and more. First, learn figure skating. Then, try freestyle. 
Good skaters look relaxed. They move easily. To be like them, do exercises. Warm up your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to stay loose.
Skating helps balance, coordination, and relaxation. It is good for your heart and lungs. Skating with swimming or jogging is great for health.

**Young Stars and Their Lives**
**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika is a gymnast. She won a gold medal at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and go to the Olympics. Annika works very hard. She does not have time to watch TV or go out with friends. She trains every day. Sometimes, when she is very tired, her coach gives her a day off.
**B. Annika's Mother**  
Annika was very good at gymnastics from a young age. Some parents push their children, but Annika wants to do it herself. Gymnastics has helped Annika become more confident. She used to be shy, but now she meets people from all over the world.
**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at age 10. She won the British National Championship. Her parents help her train and take her to shows. Sarah loves show-jumping and wants to win a gold medal at the Olympics. She is very determined.
**D. Sarah's Mother**  
Sarah loved horses from age 1. She used to get up early to exercise her pony. They travel all over England for shows. Sarah is happy and knows what she is doing on a horse. Watching her succeed is wonderful.

Jane is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. She likes chess tournaments because they are fun and friendly. Jane does not talk about her success at school because she does not like to feel embarrassed.
