Jane played chess for the first time at age 5 and loved it. She learned all the moves quickly and started beating adults by age 6. Jane's mother is happy when Jane wins, but she will support Jane if she wants to stop playing chess. Jane's mother wants her to use her talent.

"We are getting taller. Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole?' because Chris was already very tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. People in Europe are getting taller by about 1 cm every ten years. More tall people are being born. This is not because we are becoming a super race. We are becoming like our ancestors from 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different plants and animals. About 9,000 years ago, farming started. People began eating mostly wheat, rice, and corn. This was not good for health. People became less healthy and shorter. Now, in places like Europe, the US, and Japan, people eat better again. The average man in the US is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. But there are problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less space in planes and trains. We cannot grow taller forever. Scientists think we might stop growing taller at 193 cm. But, as the Earth gets warmer, we might become smaller again."

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a normal part of TV, but many people do not understand them. We see them happy on game shows and wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. Even TV workers sometimes do not respect them. I thought studio audiences were people who wanted to be famous. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of jobs and backgrounds. TV wants different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and do not understand why others go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch what you can see at home? Some think people want to be on TV for a second. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She came because she wanted to be on TV. Others are curious to see behind the scenes. But many just come because a friend gave them a ticket. Few people have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit with strangers and see signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This is true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager says, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between watching in a studio and at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is 'more exciting'. Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were far away, so I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but that is not important. For most people, it is fun and free entertainment.'

Bruce  
I like places with people. I don't like empty places. I like villages with old buildings. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to a village. I liked the hills and valleys. I am from Scotland, so the place felt like home. I wrote about my trips in a diary. Now, I write about travel for work.  
Sophia  
There is a small train from Hythe to Dungeness. I like to ride first class. The view is simple, with fields and sheep. The train goes through gardens. I see people doing everyday things, like making tea. I like the simple view. It makes me look closely.  
Matthew  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet coast. The beaches have rocks and are hard to reach. Few people come here. Some people surf, but most look at the sea. There are walks by the coast and in valleys with trees and flowers. We stay in a small house in a village.  
Annette  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is good for walking. Not many people live or visit there. I found it when I was a student. I go there every year with my family. It is special to visit with my child.  
James  
I bought my favorite house, Glenthorne. I wanted peace and to feel at home. I grew up in Sri Lanka but went to school in England. I rode my bike around the village. We had a story about Glenthorne: if you went there, you never came back. It is a quiet, special house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

'ANIMAL FUN We love animals and have many at home. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a big snake. "Can we keep it?" she asked. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We have a special box for animals to stay in for one night. I came home late. I started cooking when I heard my children shouting, "Help, Mom!" I ran to their room. Our cat, Domino, had a white mouse in his mouth. The mouse was a gift for Mother's Day. Domino ran around the room with the mouse. I tried to catch Domino but fell down. Then, I saw the snake. It was getting out of the box. The room was crazy with the cat, mouse, kids, and snake. The dog was barking too. I turned off the stove and caught Domino. I saved the mouse. The mouse lived a long life, even though Domino caught it three more times. I then looked at the snake. It was hard to catch. I sat on the floor and waited. The snake calmed down. I picked it up slowly and took it to the garden. I let it go near a tree. But the snake climbed on me like a scarf. My oldest child, DJ, said, "Mom, you are warm, and the shed is not." We helped the snake move to the tree. It went up the wall and over the roof. My little child, Clay, said, "Wow, that was a big snake!"'

'Write me a letter! Today, we use phones and computers a lot. But writing letters is special. I love getting letters. It is exciting to see who sent it and to read it. I have written letters all my life. I started with small notes to my mother. She always told me to write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy. When I was 18, I moved to London to study. I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote to me. My father also wrote funny letters sometimes. The letters talked about everyday things. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Writing letters made our relationships better. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I like letters with birthday or Christmas cards. It is nice to get news from the whole year. I also get letters from friends in other countries. I have a friend in Sri Lanka, one in Australia, and one in Canada. I also have a friend in France. We met in a restaurant and started writing to each other. She writes in French, and I practice my French with her. We have visited each other. My biggest letter-writing success was meeting my American friend in Texas. We wrote letters for 29 years before we met. People were surprised our friendship lasted so long. My children also write letters. They have penfriends in Texas. I think writing letters is important. Do not let it disappear.'

**Title: Tourists Damage Old Rock Art in France**
In France, there are very old pictures on rocks in the mountains. These pictures are 4,000 years old. They show cows, fields, and gods. Many people visit this place to see the pictures.
But, some tourists are not careful. They write on the rocks and damage the pictures. Some people even take pieces of the rock home. This is bad for the pictures.
Jean Clottes is an expert on rock art. He says if people keep damaging the pictures, they will be gone in 50 years. Some people want to close the area to protect the pictures. Others think people should still visit but with guides.
Annie Echassoux, another expert, says the area is easier to reach now, so more people visit. She thinks guides and ropes can help protect the pictures. She believes money must be found to save the pictures for the future.

**Shopping with Children**
Shopping with children can be hard. One mother says, "They want everything. They see cereal, videos, and comics. I can't buy all these things. I feel bad when I say no, but I also feel bad when I buy them. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn to choose."
Research shows children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, mostly on TV. These ads make children want things. Parents find it hard to explain why they can't buy everything. Ads make things look fun and exciting.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Parents care about what their children eat. They have ideas about healthy food, but ads give children a different view. Parents don't like competing with ads and saying no to their children."
TV ads can't tell children to ask parents to buy things, but they still make children want to buy. Parents feel stressed deciding what to buy. One mother talks to her children about ads and food. Her son now thinks ads are not true, so they have fewer problems in the store.

'Climbing Walls Long ago, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. The National Indoor Arena, where the event is held, is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both have a big wall. In the past, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they walked or climbed in Scotland. To stay fit, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. Later, sports centers built special climbing walls. Don Robinson, a teacher, made a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock in concrete. Many walls like this were built in the 1970s. But these walls had problems. They were only straight up and down. Real cliffs have different shapes. In 1985, Francois Savigny from France made new climbing shapes. These could be put on walls and changed when needed. French companies also made panels with steel frames. These were lighter and could be moved easily. Climbers could have new challenges all the time.'

'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they might say it is "risky." Acting is a risky job. There are many actors, but not many jobs. Some friends might say you are crazy, but others might not. Everyone will give different advice. It is your choice, and you must be responsible for it. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee you will get a job after training. You need luck and talent. People want new faces and talent. Acting can be exciting and glamorous. Talent is natural skill and imagination. It also needs courage and belief in yourself. Why do people want to act? It is hard to say. In the theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is important in all acting. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job. Disappointment is hard for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. Actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle stress and rejection. Nobody likes rejection. From the start, you say you are ready and talented for the job. It is up to you. If you do not care, no one else will.'

'Cookbooks for Everyone We have some great cookbooks for you. A. Delia Smith is a famous TV cook and writer. Her recipes are from all over the world. Her book, Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course, is very popular. It has many easy and tasty recipes. It helps you cook better. B. Raymond Blanc is a famous chef. He has a book called Blanc Mange. It has over 80 recipes. Raymond explains how cooking works. He wants to help you cook better. C. Le Cordon Bleu is a famous cooking school. They have a book called Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook. It has 100 recipes. The book shows you how to cook French food. It has pictures to help you. D. Nigel Slater is a food writer. He has a book called The 30-Minute Cook. It has over 200 recipes. You can make them in 30 minutes. Nigel shows you how to make fast and tasty food.'

"We are getting taller. Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole?' because Chris was already very tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. People in Europe are getting taller by about one centimeter every ten years. More tall people are being born. This is not because we are becoming a super race. We are becoming like our ancestors from 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different plants and animals. About 9,000 years ago, farming started. People began eating mostly wheat, rice, and corn. This made people less healthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became less healthy. But farming could feed more people. Now, in Europe, the US, and Japan, people eat better again. The average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. But there are problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less space in planes and trains. We cannot grow forever. Scientists think we might stop growing taller at 193 cm. But, as the Earth gets warmer, we might get smaller again."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He lost his job suddenly. He used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel. The chef helped him sell his meat. Now, he sells meat by mail too. He works a lot, but he is happy not to be in an office.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They did not know anyone there. They left their friends, but their friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats. She liked her job, but the hours were long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People said she would get bored, but she did not. She likes having deadlines. She is happier and less stressed now. She misses talking to colleagues. She likes being responsible for her work.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health. He visited gyms and talked to owners. He took courses in massage. Now, he works part-time and feels in control of his life.

'Two Brothers and a Game Dave and Norm Lagasse are brothers. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They like to play a game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada. The family played the game a lot. They had fun. One day, Dave made a new pichenotte board. People liked it. They wanted to play too. Dave and Norm took the game to a bar. People watched and played. They liked it very much. Pichenotte is a game for two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces. You flick the pieces with your finger. You try to get them into a hole. The game is short, only two minutes. The brothers started to sell the boards. They made many boards. They sell them for $595 each. The brothers hope the game will make them rich.'

'WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE When you come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land with lots of bushes. One man and his wife worked very hard to make it beautiful. They moved a lot of soil to make the land look nice. They used big machines and also worked a lot by hand. They put new soil on top to make grass, flowers, and rocks. Many trees and plants were put in the village. These plants had to be strong because the village is near the sea and it can be very windy. Some plants came from far away places like Canada and New Zealand. Colin Sims made the village. He made over 100 small buildings in nine years. He used stone, wood, and plastic to make them strong. At first, he needed help to learn about the materials, but soon he became very good at it. The village is very popular because it looks real and is well made. The small buildings show British styles. One big building is the Manor House, which looks like a house from the 13th century. You can also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course. Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. You can take pictures from the paths. Dogs can come if they are on a short lead. Some models can move if you press a button. At the end of your visit, please tell us what you think. We are always making new models and want to know your ideas. We hope you have a good time and come back again. Tell your friends about us.'

'Every week, British newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. Pop stars sometimes pose for photos, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments. Few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that helps with these problems. These pictures do not help the public. For example, a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony does not help anyone. The actress was upset about these pictures before, but she did not complain. The PCC did not investigate, which is surprising. They should also look into a story about a pop star's love life. The pop star did not complain either. Should the PCC do something about these attacks? It seems like a good idea. It would stop newspapers from publishing such pictures. Photographers would not make money from these photos. But if the PCC acted like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would they decide to investigate? Should they ask the victim to complain? If the person does nothing, should the PCC still act? Celebrities might expect the PCC to help them, and be upset if it doesn't. The PCC cannot watch all newspapers and magazines. Also, people might not want more attention from an investigation. Most people want to forget and move on. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story they want to hide. Even the PCC could become a problem. A British comedian was photographed on his honeymoon and family holiday. He did not complain because he feared the newspaper would make fun of him. People think they will be targets if they challenge the newspapers. This is a difficult problem to solve.'

'There is a lot of advice for students who finish college and start their first job. This article talks about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a temporary job or leaving a bad job quickly. We are talking about people who want to move up in their career. You have some skills and know what you want. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to be an expert in one area, get more responsibility, or try something new? Choose your second job carefully. You should stay in it for two to three years. This job is important for your next job application. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see you have traveled and are ready to work. Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after college. It was a good first job. She learned office work and improved her skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she left, traveled for a year, and now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, a Chief Executive. Juliette says, 'In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has grown.' Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She now does more important work like handling correspondence and budgets. She also answers questions from company leaders and people starting businesses. Brenda gives her projects and events to organize.'

'How to be confident? Confident people look like they were born that way, but they learned it. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school, I was very shy. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I was scared, but I did well. Someone said I should go to university. I was nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life. B Michaela Four years ago, my father got sick, and I took over the family business. I was scared and too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I save tasks for the next day. When things are difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to forget my fears. C Lisa People think I'm confident, but when I look calm, I'm scared. In TV, you must look confident. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous. My mom said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone worries about themselves.' I remember this. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared. D Barbara I enjoy my work, and that gives me confidence. I learn from mistakes and become more confident. I work hard and am liked, but not everyone likes me. I don't let it bother me. You must like yourself. My company has training courses that help my confidence. We set small goals and see our progress. E Kim After college, I was a secretary. I was scared to speak in meetings. I started to speak up. In politics, I was nervous speaking in public. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' I wrote notes to help me. Everyone is a little nervous speaking in public. Confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.''

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You can keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition. If the line breaks, the finder keeps the kite. I have many more.' He showed me a pile of kites. They were all 120cm wide and long, made of paper and bamboo. We sat under the trees near the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan. We watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach, there were 10 platforms. Helpers held the kites, and people waited to fly them. When the whistle blew, the kites went up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition. It lasts five days every year. They entered four different kite designs. The kites were judged on decoration, how well they flew, and how stable they were. 'Flying kites is easy,' said Adnan, 'but making them is hard. Come to my house, and I'll show you.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to fix his kite, but I couldn't. I explored the south of the state. I drove towards Kuala Lumpur, into the mountains with rainforests. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. I saw a sign that said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' The path was steep and slippery. At the track, a man named Baba was waiting with tea. He had a tented kitchen and bamboo huts. I stayed there, trying not to think about insects. The night was very dark and noisy. A waterfall was nearby, and many animals made sounds. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. The wind and lightning hit the trees. I got very wet. Going downhill, I saw big butterflies. I worried about my car being washed away. But the car was still there, covered in mud. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' They were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for kites, but I remember the kind people.'

'What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which one you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I love shopping! I spend a lot of money. When I have money, I go shopping and I feel happy. My boyfriend is the same, so we shop together. We love shopping! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I don't like shopping. My husband buys the food because he cooks. I don't buy clothes often. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't like it. We like different things. I don't spend money on myself often. When I do, I feel bad and I don't tell my husband how much I spend. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for things I need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. I know what I want and I don't buy other things. Shopping makes me tired. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes. I know what I want and where to find it. I shop quickly. I have some clothes I don't wear, so maybe I make mistakes sometimes. E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't like shopping. I don't like shopping for clothes because I can't find what I want. The shops are noisy and messy. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. I buy food once a week. F. Lisa, 22, actress I am a happy shopper. I go shopping with my friends and we buy things. I don't look for something special, but if I like something, I buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I am a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I know what I want and I don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I feel bad if I spend too much. H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but not on busy days like Saturday. I am careful. I know what I want and I look in many shops for a good price. I take a long time. I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I don't like shopping. I work in the city, so shops are not fun for me. When I shop, I don't try clothes on. Sometimes clothes don't fit, but I don't mind. I don't want to spend a lot of time shopping.'

'LEARN WITH THE OPEN UNIVERSITY The Open University is like other universities. It can give you a degree. You can study and work at the same time. You can learn many new things. You will enjoy learning. You will make new friends. Your degree can help you get a new job. You study at home. You use TV, radio, and computer. You can go to one class a month at the Open University. You have exams like other universities. If you want to know more, fill out the form below. It can be a great new start for you.'

'Little Chefs On Saturdays, children aged ten to fifteen learn to cook. The cooking classes are very popular. There is a waiting list of 30 children. Parents pay £280 for the course. Children have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made.' Flora is twelve and finds cutting onions hard. 'I love cooking. I cooked for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby. I was happy at home, so I didn't want to go at first. But now I'm glad I came.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's fun. Children learn better than adults, but the kitchen is not always tidy! If children learn cooking when they are young, they can cook for themselves when they grow up.''

'MONEY What is money? Money is like a gram or a kilometre. But you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. The note is just a piece of paper. Long ago, people did not have money. There were no banks or shops. Mr Green, a farmer, gave his corn to Mr Hive for honey. They traded things they needed. Later, people made their own 'currencies' to trade more easily. Now, every country has its own money.'

'Write a story and win! You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize. Your story will be in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people will win £100. We want people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a writer, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and new stories. Last year, detective stories were popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything. Here is some advice: Write about what you know. Last year, many people wrote about love, family, and friends. Make ordinary things interesting. Make the reader want to read more. Get your facts right. Do not write about things you do not know. Hold the reader's attention. Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. Think about the characters. Make them seem real. Your story must be your own work. It should be 2,000 to 2,500 words. Type it on one side of each paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. Include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have been on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story. The closing date is 30 July. We will tell the winner within one month. If you win, your story will be in our magazine.'

'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the only woman scientist in history books for many years. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He made sure Hypatia had a good education. This was special because most women could not study then. Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then she went back to Alexandria to teach mathematics. She became famous for her new ideas. We do not have her books now, but she wrote important math books. Hypatia also liked technology and made some science tools. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people who liked science were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked and killed in the street.'

'Grass Grass is a very successful plant. There are over 9,000 types of grass. Grass is everywhere on Earth. It can live in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Many animals live in grasslands. Small insects, birds, cows, and lions all need grass. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut. New leaves grow from below the soil. This helps many animals live in one place. When animals eat the grass, it grows back fast, so they have more to eat.'

'Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. As a child, Kal liked to draw clothes. Her parents own a supermarket, and she did not tell them she wanted to work in fashion. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in advertising. She needed nice clothes for work events but could not buy expensive ones. So, she made her own skirts and tops. Her friends liked them and asked her to make clothes for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her clothes. They sold well, so she left her job and started her own clothing business with a PS20,000 loan. Her parents were happy and supported her. Now, her clothes are in over 70 stores, and her business makes over PS500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, and she designs for pop stars. She is happy to win the award and says, "I love my job, but I worked hard for it."'

'SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel is a big hotel. It was built in 1913. Princess Louise opened it. Many people from different countries stay here. The hotel is on a main road. It is 20 minutes by bus from the town centre. Buses stop outside the hotel. Do not take buses with a blue Express sign. They do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station 100 metres away. The hotel has 200 rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers and toilets are at the end of the hall. Dinner can be until 11 pm if you ask before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner. No animals or fires are allowed. Keep noise low, especially from 11 pm to 8 am. Use taxis from the train station to the hotel. It is far from the main railway station.'

'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is a very famous actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a boy, Tom was shy and did not have many friends. He liked acting in school plays. After High School, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, Tom was very successful and made a lot of money. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.'

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? Bo is a cat. One day, Bo went into a big truck. The truck went very far, more than 500 kilometres. The driver found Bo at the end of the day. Both the driver and Bo were hungry! The driver gave Bo some milk. He called people to find Bo's owner, but no one lost a cat. It was late, so the driver took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took Bo to an animal hospital. Bo's owner was looking for her too. He remembered the truck that came to his neighbor's house. He called the truck company. Soon, Bo went home safely.'

'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway took a train trip from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the cold south. People call it the 'famous Ghan', but it is often late. A train line from Adelaide to Alice Springs was made in the 1920s, but there was a lot of flooding. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The train is not very fast and most people on it are on holiday. The Ghan is not a luxury train, but the food is very good. The railway was first made to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money. The Ghan says it is the world's first north-south railway. When I waited to get on the Ghan, everyone was excited. Most of the people on the train were older Australians. Our first stop was Katherine, where the train waited for four hours. Some people took a boat trip. I got off at Alice Springs and went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. We walked around the rock and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people stop here. After Alice Springs, the view is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land and cattle. On the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My trip was over. The train did not do everything the ads said, but it took me to some amazing places in Australia.'

'Climbing Ben Nevis
Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, my first big winter climb. We climbed the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters up - the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain. We had tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need them because the snow is very hard, like ice. Some people in the group were very good climbers. We took safety things like lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather was good, with no strong winds, but we were still a little nervous. Ben Nevis in winter is always hard. The path went up and my legs felt tired. I was the slowest in the group, so I stopped more. The others waited for me, but when I got there, they started again. I told myself to train more next time. After 200 meters, we started Tower Ridge. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain is very steep on each side. We had to stay calm and watch every step. After seven hours, we got to the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we saw mist. Going back down to camp is also hard. You need to read a map well. A wrong turn can be dangerous. I was happy we took turns with the map. I only felt happy when I was safe in the tent. But I made it to the top.'

Anna's New School
This week is very exciting. We moved to a new school building! The school is made of wood, like our old school. It is special because it is good for the environment. It took a long time to build. We watched the builders work. It was noisy, and sometimes they stopped because of the rain. We thought it would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms. They are bigger than the ones in our old school. We also have a room for town meetings, a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We will use the changing rooms when the new sports field is ready.
When you come to our school, you see there are no heaters. The heat comes from us, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat and sound inside. When we sing, it sounds like a concert hall!
There is a tree on the roof. The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We saw it yesterday. It is very big and goes around fast. We took pictures for our website.
We are using the new school, but some parts are not ready yet. We have to go to the old school hall for plays. The new hall will be ready next year. We are happy with our new school. Our teachers say we will learn faster here!

'A Fun Weekend A month ago, I did not know I would be rock-climbing in November. Now, I am 30 meters above the ground and I like it. I look down at the river and understand why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I came to the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place to stay was not great, but we had beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met ten other people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would be outside for the weekend, but we did not know what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning, and the others went rock-climbing. Then we changed at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we were out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited.'

'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my bag on the bus. In my bag, I had my cheque book, address book, and my wallet with about £50 and some credit cards. When I knew I lost it, it was too late. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me money for the bus home. I told the bus driver my story, and he said I should keep the money. I got home safely. Soon, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the bus company. He said they had my bag and he would bring it to me. I got my bag back with everything inside. I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me. They were very kind and honest. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

'Sharks Sharks are big fish in the ocean. They can see very well and feel movement in the water. This helps them catch smaller fish to eat. Sharks are different from other fish. Most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and live, so they do not sleep much. If you turn a shark on its back, it stops moving. This helps people who study sharks learn more about them.'

Bus from Sydney to Melbourne via Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights in hotels with breakfast. 'Joining the Kirov Ballet
Hello, I am Nathalie. Last year, I joined the Kirov Ballet School in St Petersburg, Russia. I was nervous at my first ballet class because I did not know anyone. People asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke English, so we talked. Now, after six months, my Russian is better, and I understand my teachers. 
My mum stayed with me for two weeks when I arrived. I was sad when she left. One night, I called her because I felt lonely. The ballet classes in Russia are hard, and I eat a lot to have energy. This helps me do well in school. In the evenings, I watch films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep.
I like living here now. I enjoy walking in the city and visiting shops. In December, it was very cold, minus 10°C, so I bought a fur hat. The Russians said it was not very cold for December! My room is warm and cosy.
We are preparing for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers. I will join the competition. I feel very lucky to be here.'

'THE ICEHOTEL The Arctic is a cold place. In summer, people visit to see the midnight sun. In winter, it is very cold and dark. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit made an art show in a snow building in Jukkasjarvi, a small town. This building was called Arctic Hall. Some visitors slept there one night and liked it. This gave the idea for the ICEHOTEL. Now, the ICEHOTEL is famous. Every winter, people come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They use snow and ice. The hotel opens in parts. The first part opens in December. The hotel is finished by January 7th. The hotel melts in spring when it gets warm. Inside the hotel, it is -5°C to -8°C. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves. It is good to bring sweaters, scarves, and thick socks. You can buy these on the ICEHOTEL website. They will be in your room when you arrive. The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It is 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people, about 6,000, went to the shop. There were special offers. A leather sofa was on sale for £45 until 3 am. A bed was on sale for £30 between 3 am and 8 am. The shop's normal hours are 9 am to 9 pm every day. But for the first day, it was open for 24 hours. However, the shop closed after 30 minutes. A police officer said: 'We knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside were angry. They thought everything would sell before they could enter. They did not want to wait quietly. Also, many cars were trying to get to the car park. Some people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours. I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained the situation. It was not safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I will not wait in line again.'

'Membership The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899. It is a big arts group in Britain. Society Magazines We make magazines like the Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by top writers in Britain. New writers can also have their work printed. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers. It has information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can read some articles on our website. National Short Story Competition We have the National Short Story Competition. It is the biggest competition like this. Anyone aged 18 and over can join. Stories can be about any topic. They should be 1,000 to 1,500 words long. Members do not pay to enter (non-members pay PS5). The competition is from April to October. The ten best stories will be in the Society's book. The winner gets a contract to make a book of short stories. Education For almost thirty years, the Society has helped writers in schools. We give new ideas to children and teachers. We help them feel good about writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year. It started in 1998. It is for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can study with writers for five days. The Writers' Cafe The Writers' Cafe is the social place of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish. It has vegetarian food, coffee, and cold drinks. It is a good place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe has exhibitions, short courses, and readings every month. It is in the center of London. It is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on some products and events. Becoming a Member We have members all over the world. Anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.'

'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter is very good at free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean with one breath. In 2003, Tanya Streeter dived 120 meters deep without help. She held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people say free-diving is dangerous, but Tanya says it is safe if you train well. Tanya trains a lot. She spends most of her time training in the gym. She also trains in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because it can hurt her knees. She likes fast walking to stay fit. When she practices diving, she travels away from home. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with rest days in between. It is important for her not to get tired. When Tanya is not diving, she talks to people about sports and helps the environment. She grew up on the island of Grand Cayman in the Caribbean. She loved swimming and watching sea life as a child. Tanya says her life now is like her childhood dreams. She is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties and wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and does not want to stop for many years.'

'CARTOON MOVIES Cartoon movies can show anything. If you can draw it, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun for everyone. In the 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for kids. But some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids could enjoy cartoons. Not all cartoon movies were good. The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for kids and too simple for adults. Directors learned from this, and movie companies started making money again.'

'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role. "I never thought I would act in The Finnegans during my first year at university. I only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I wanted to play her. I took a year off to travel before university. In Chile, my mother emailed me about the book becoming a TV show. I wanted to try for the part. My mother sent my photo to the director, and he met me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to leave for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6.00am to write essays. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and liked it. It was amazing. After university, I want to be an actress. My family is not in acting, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I tried for other TV roles but got no offers yet. I don't know how I did it all because I had a busy social life too. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do. I acted in two college plays. I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over. I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."'

'The Body Shop' Story
In 1976, I opened the first 'Body Shop'. I wanted to make money to feed my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' is a big company in many countries. I learned a lot since we started. I wrote this book to share what I learned. 
This book is not just about business or my life. It says that to do well in business, you need to be different. Business can be fun and full of love. It can also do good things. In business and life, I want to be happy, feel like family, and enjoy surprises. I want people who work at 'The Body Shop' to feel the same.
This book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and what we can do. I think this is exciting. I hope you think so, too.

'A TRIP ON THE DOURO RIVER
Jules Verne has a 'hotel ship' on the Douro river in Portugal. The ship is called MV Lady Ivy May. It can take 160 people. The rooms have a shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.
Day 1: You leave London Heathrow in the evening and fly to Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the ship. You will sleep on the ship.
Day 2: In the morning, you will see Oporto. Then, you go back to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This takes four hours.
Day 3: You travel up the river. In the evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua. You can try local food and drink at dinner.
Day 4: After breakfast, you go by bus to Lamego. You visit the cathedral, churches, and a museum. The museum was a palace. It has paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Then, you go back to the ship and sail to Tua.
Day 5: The river is narrow here. You might take a small boat to Barca d'Alva in Spain. You return to Tua by coach and see many things.
Day 6: In the morning, you drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. You return to the ship for lunch. Then, you take a train ride to Regua. The ship will be there.
Day 7: You visit Vila Real. Then, you go back to the ship for lunch and travel down the river to Oporto. You sleep on the ship.
Day 8: You arrive in Oporto. You have time to see the city and shop before flying back to London Heathrow.'

'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It has water and sugars. Bees travel very far and visit many flowers to make honey. The colour and taste of honey come from the flowers. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Light honey is usually less strong in taste than dark honey. Long ago, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was hard to find. The ancient Egyptians used honey as money. Today, people make and eat honey everywhere in the world. Honey can help with tiredness and make you better at sports. Honey is not just food - it can help sore throats and is used in many skin and hair products.'

'Norwich Norwich is a city in East Anglia, a part of Britain. People have lived there for more than 2,000 years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. In 1066, it was one of the biggest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, so it is important for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095. Norwich became a city in 1194. Today, Norwich is smaller than London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second biggest city in England. It was famous for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs. In 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many things to do: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. Norwich also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors. The city has a modern shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. Builders made a big hole in the city to build it. The roof of the Mall is now a park with water pools and trees. The old market is still in the city centre, next to the new shopping centre. Both places are popular, showing that Norwich has a mix of old and new.'

'The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every year in autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-west of the United States, is full of bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival. It lasts for nine days. The first festival was in 1972 for a radio station's 50th birthday. There were about twelve balloons then. Now, there are about a thousand balloons from many countries. What to see The balloon pilots talk to each other on the radio. They light up their balloons at the same time. This is called a 'balloon glow'. You can take great photos. Come after dark or before 5:30 am to see the 'glows'. During the day, you can walk around and talk to the pilots. The balloons are different sizes and colors. Some look like animals or cartoon characters. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can fly in a balloon over the desert. You can also take a cable car to the top of the mountains and see the festival from above. There are many things to do, like balloon races and fireworks. The Albuquerque Box This is a special wind pattern. The Sandia Mountains help the balloons by stopping strong winds. Pilots can move their balloons by going up or down. Practical advice Buy your tickets online to avoid long lines. Wear layers of clothes. It is cool at night and in the morning, but you need sunglasses and suncream during the day. Bring a flashlight for night events and a camera. If you use film, bring high-speed film for night pictures.'

'The Eden Project The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists to visit. The Eden Project has big 'biospheres'. They look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. This shows how important plants are to people. Many things we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. There are over 135,000 types of plants here. Even if it is cold outside, heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. Another zone is like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. There are plans to make a desert zone soon.'

'New Writing 3 Book Some people do not like this year's book, New Writing 3. I do not know why. The book has 500 pages of new writing for only £6.99. This is very good! Most of the book is stories. There are parts of novels and short stories. Famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain wrote some stories. Some writers who are not famous wrote about food. Jane Harris wrote a story called Those Nails. Do not read it after eating. It has some bad scenes. There are poems by nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are parts of novels by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. There is also a little non-fiction. Alan Rusbridger wrote a funny article about newspapers. Ursula Owen wrote about herself. This is a great book. I am excited to see next year's book.'

'Learning the Violin "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violin teacher. Margaret lives in London. She likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but sometimes she teaches five-year-olds too. Margaret started teaching the violin in 1972. Her first class was with her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students. Each lesson is one hour long and happens every two weeks. Each student also has one lesson alone with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons. At first, students learn to play by listening. They do not read music for many years. There is a big difference between their playing and reading music. Margaret says her way is not to make great violinists. She suggests that very good students should leave and learn the violin in a different way.

'Moonshine The band Moonshine made a new CD last week. The CD is called 'Here Again'. It comes after their last CD, 'The Waves'. There are some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott plays bass guitar now. He replaced Simon McVee, who left last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer. The first song on the CD is a dance song. The band is not only making slow songs now. The second song is also a dance song and is louder. Most of the other songs are slow. These two dance songs might surprise fans. They are very good and could be popular. The singer, Rob Letchford, sings very well on the CD. He recorded the songs before he had a problem with his throat. The band had to cancel their next tour because of this. People who bought tickets do not need to worry. The concerts will happen later when Rob is better. On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make different kinds of music. Some songs are slow, and some are for dancing. The best songs are at the start of the CD. The last songs are not as good. But 'Here Again' will still be a big success for the band.'

'San Francisco San Francisco is in northern California, near the ocean. The first Europeans to find the area came with a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it first in 1769. San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbour, but it was found from the land, not the sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to look for gold. But the people who got rich were not the gold seekers. The richest people owned banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists like to visit San Francisco. They can see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.'

'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote a very famous diary in English. The diary talks about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about big news, like sickness, enemy ships on the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself. He sometimes slept in church or looked at pretty girls. He talks about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and his worry about her being sick. Pepys liked books, music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. He was a busy man with many important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

'The History of Shoes Long ago, people did not care if shoes were comfortable or nice. They used animal skins to cover their feet in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but also silk, plastic, and cotton, depending on fashion. About 150 years ago, people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could fit on either foot. All shoes were made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped make many shoes quickly and cheaply.'

'Running Club for Women When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women try running. I wanted to show them it is fun and help them feel good about running. I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because some race organizers did not have changing rooms for women. I made posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. They wanted to lose weight, but they did not think about running before. They thought running was hard and painful. They did not think about running and talking with friends in nice places, like near a river. At first, they ran for one minute. Now, they can run for thirty minutes. They also learned about food and fitness from other runners. I wanted to help women run, and I am happy to see them get better. They are happy too.'

'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there to find gold. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod. This town grew very fast in 1909 and was the biggest city in Alaska for a short time. In summer, boats could bring things to these towns, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze. So, in 1910, a winter path was made for dogs to pull sleds. They took mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for the dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when planes started to be used instead. But in 1925, a disease called diphtheria was in the city of Nome. The medicine was far away in Anchorage. Planes were new, and it was too cold to fly. The only good pilot was not there. So, they used dog teams to take the medicine. The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to finish. Leonhard Seppala, from Norway, traveled the first 400 kilometers. His dog Togo helped him in the snow. The last part was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had worked with dogs in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. Balto saved the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Now, there is a dog sled race every year from Anchorage to Nome. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, it can be very cold, even -40°C. But 6,000 people visit every year. They come to see a special hotel. This hotel is made of ice. You can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even get married there. The bar is also ice, so do not put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C. Guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. You can also get warm clothes if you need them. The hotel melts in summer, so it is new every winter. Building the hotel needs 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on a boys' team in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' A local newspaper wrote about her, and a man named Jose Craveirinha read it. He helped other African athletes before. He went to see Maria and saw her playing football. He saw she was very fast. 'He talked to me about running. I did not know what he meant. I only knew football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard, and my legs hurt.' Jose talked to her parents and said she could be successful and help her family. They agreed to let her train. In 1991, she went to the United States to train. She did not want to go before because she would miss her family. The girls in the US were different from her. She says, 'They were good at sports, but I worried about my family having food, and they worried about clothes and make-up. They did not know much about me or my problems. But I was happy to be there. The trainers were very good, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs and lives in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.'

'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon is in the United States. The River Colorado made the Grand Canyon. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and look at the view. The view is very nice because of the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor. You can see the rocks of the canyon. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007. Many people have used it. You must wear special covers on your shoes to keep the glass clean. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying like a bird.'

'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains are in North America. They start in the North-west and go to the south. The Rockies are smaller than the Alps, but they are very beautiful. You can see the Rockies by car, but the best way is by train. You start in Vancouver, a big city in Canada. Vancouver is near the water and the mountains. People can ski 15 minutes from the city. Before, 30 trains left Vancouver every day. Now, only three trains go each week. The train trip is fun. You sleep on the train, but you see some nice places at night.'

'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China had a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals in zoos did tricks for visitors. Now, animals in zoos act naturally. Today, many cities have a zoo or wildlife park. Some people like zoos because they help us learn about animals and see them up close. But some people do not like zoos. They think it is not good to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and eat bad food.'

'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with other high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different clothes. My band wore black school uniforms, and some bands wore bright T-shirts. We are young, but we play very well. Some players made new music on stage. It was fun to watch, but I liked it best when my band played! We have a good jazz band at my school, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the people who want to join get in. But anyone who wants to play can come to practice before school. We also listen to jazz after school. We go to jazz camps in the summer, too. I have been to a few and learned a lot. Adults are surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher says pop music is not hard enough for people who love music. I like jazz because it is new and old. You can make your own music and feel part of jazz history. My school is lucky. We have great teachers and parents who help us. Without them, we could not play music!'

'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain between November and March. It does not rain often, and when it rains a lot, the streets can flood. People in Marrakesh are happy when it rains because many winters are dry. Marrakesh has parks and gardens. They have water from underground channels. These channels were made in the 11th century. They bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places with water like this are called oases. South of Marrakesh is Skoura. In Skoura, people use water channels to grow food. The Atlas mountains, with snow in winter, are in the background.'

'Gareth Ellis Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers. They work in banks and with computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. 'People laugh when we tell them,' says Kath. 'But it's true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old.' When Alan lost his job, he and Kath looked for circus jobs. They got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started learning to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers take care of the house when they are away. 'It was not easy,' says Kath. 'We had a lot to think about. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in. We left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths.' 'People ask about my school,' says Gareth, 'but everywhere we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my school friends, and I have a computer. I am not behind in my school work.' And the future? 'It was a hard choice,' says Kath, 'but it was the only way for Gareth to learn to be a clown. I am happy it is working, and we like it.' And Gareth? 'I will be the main clown in a circus one day,' he says, 'maybe Bippo's circus.''

'Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. Our members are 8-18 years old. We collect news and write stories. We send these stories to newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. You can read or listen to our stories on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three places where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more places. Our news group started in 1994. It was called 'Young News' before. More than 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they talked to me for a story about hip hop music. I saw young people working as journalists. Age did not matter. They did the stories by themselves. I went to the Eight-eighteen place in my city, learned a lot, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me a lot. I got a job at 19. Now, I work at a big news website.' Join Eight-eighteen When you join, you will learn and join meetings every month. You will help decide who writes each story. Older members help new members learn. They teach them how to write news. Sometimes, they teach outside Eight-eighteen too. Older staff help them. Eight-eighteen has training for new members three times a year. The next training is in February. If you want to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874. The Eight-eighteen program is good for all children who can read and write. It is free to join and there is no test.'

**Antarctica Flights Website**
Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.
**About the Flight**
- We fly from Sydney, Australia, to Antarctica and back in a big plane (Boeing 747).
- The flight is 12 hours long.
- We see ice and icebergs after four hours.
- We spend four hours over Antarctica.
- Experts talk about Antarctica on the plane.
- You can see what the pilot sees on a screen.
**Seats**
- You get two seats during the flight.
- Business and first class: window seat for half the flight.
- Economy: window or near window seat for half the flight.
- You can walk around to see better.
**Weather**
- We have 17 flight plans.
- The captain chooses the best one for clear views.
**Wildlife**
- We do not see penguins or animals because they are far below.
- We do not land in Antarctica.
**Photos**
- You can take photos.
- We have fun photo times with cold weather clothes.

'Little Chefs Some children aged ten to fifteen go to cooking classes on Saturdays. These classes are very popular. There are 30 children waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course. Children have fun and learn to cook good food. Bill is ten years old. He says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can cook better than her. The teachers are funny, especially when we eat the food we made.' Flora is twelve. She finds cutting onions hard. 'I love cooking. I cooked for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby. I was happy at home, so I didn't want to go at first. But now I'm glad I came.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's fun. Children listen and remember better than adults. But the kitchen is not always tidy! Adults always learn more about food. If parents teach children to cook when they are young, they can cook for themselves when they grow up.''

'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous for driving. It is hard to know what will happen. Accidents can happen easily. Fog can be on top of a hill. Ice can be under the snow. The car coming to you can slide. Rule Number One: drive smoothly on icy roads. Do not make sudden moves. Be gentle and slow when you turn, brake, or speed up. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive so you do not spill it. Rule Number Two: pay attention. Look far ahead on icy roads. Test stopping by braking gently. You may be driving faster than you think. Allow more space to stop when roads are wet or icy. Try to stay in control of your car to avoid trouble.'

'Craigie Aitchison Craigie Aitchison was a painter. He was born in Scotland. He went to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. He found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. In his late twenties, he got money from Italy to study art. He liked early Italian artists. He loved the green and brown fields in Italy and the light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colors from light to dark. He says he never knows what the painting will look like. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself.' Aitchison makes painting sound easy. 'Anyone can use colors - you can buy them.' He does not draw before painting. He thinks he might get bored if he did. He changes his paintings many times. He likes models who do not ask to see the painting while he works. 'If they want to look, I can't do it.' He does not feel part of the Scottish painting scene. He paints his own way. But his work still helps young British painters.'

'Rock Band Two years ago, our son Ben, who is 14 years old, asked us for drums for his birthday. At first, we said no because of the noise. Ben said, 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games, and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we said yes. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, Ben's band friends came to our house with their guitars and other things. So, for a few hours each week, the house is loud with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby is good for us: when the band plays, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must say, even if their music sounds strange, they are nice and polite boys. I don't know if they are good at music, but they play in local clubs for young people. We worry they won't study enough because of the band, but this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important school is. But one thing is sure - Ben was right: it keeps him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

'Atlantic College Last week I visited Atlantic College, a private school in Wales. It is special because it helps young people learn about life outside the classroom and study for exams. The students are 16 to 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution. Students come from different countries and backgrounds. Not many can pay the PS20,000 fees for two years, so there are grants. A quarter of the students are British, and many get government help. "I admire the college for encouraging international understanding," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect people, even those you don't like. My mother noticed I argued less with my sister during the summer holidays." In short, Atlantic College gives students a great education with methods that work.'

'Being an older student I am 32 years old and I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes, read books, and write long papers. I went back to school after 14 years. Before, I worked as a secretary. I made good money, but I was bored. I wanted to think more. I saw students at the local university. They looked happy and hopeful. I wanted to be like them. Now, I am a student, but it is hard to make friends with younger students. They think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because they know more than me. But I am happy to study because I want a good job. I like reading on weekends more than going to parties. I also like the long holidays and discounts for movies and theatre. Sometimes, I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school was a good idea.'

'Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. He drove it for 1,500 kilometers, then sold it. He made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T'. It cost $825. He sold 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap. But there was less choice. 'You can have any color you like,' said Henry Ford of the Model T, 'as long as it's black.'
